39793985.review:
Plenty of games claim to be retro or retro-inspired, but it’s a tough label to do justice. The classic NES titles that inform so many indie games now were products of very different times and sensibilities, and much of what worked then doesn’t fly today. That’s what makes games like Odallus so special, because they manage to bring the good parts of retro design forward and merge them with modern concepts. The result is an adventure that looks and feels like the games you grew up with, but plays with all the intelligent balance and conveniences you’ve grown to appreciate.

The old gods are dead, and the new ones are not the kind and forgiving type. In fact, they like to torch towns and carry off children, which is precisely what happens to your William Wallace-looking hero Haggis. He’ll have to travel a dark fantasy world of crumbling ruins and haunted forests to reach the castle of the evil deity who ruined his life, and kill hundreds of twisted creatures along the way. There’s also plenty of ancient secrets to unearth like legendary swords and armors, inscriptions of the past, and relics that can grant Haggis fantastic new powers.

It’s something of a level-based metroidvania, where each stage features open spaces and multiple paths to explore in search of new treasures and secrets. “Vast” is a completely apt term for the realms you’ll traverse, too, because it can be quite a hike or series of jumps to reach the distant corners where goodies lie hidden. Right from the start there are blocks to push and climb on, hidden walls to tear down, and ledges to mantle up. That last one is key not just to exploration but to gamefeel, as you can hang from any ledge and pull yourself up to reach new areas. Needless to say it’ll also save you from some frustrating falls, and will also be used for its own tricky platforming challenges in later areas.

Mantling up is a prime example of how Odallus brings modern sensibilities to classic gameplay. Without it the controls would stray towards the old pre-Iga Castlevanias with their stiff movements and all-or-nothing leaps. But the tight air control and mantling option opens up the levels to free exploration, and the later character upgrades open it up even further. Aside from the usual double-jump there’s a cloak that slows your descents, a dash move, a bracer that lets you move huge blocks, and the ability to breathe underwater. Because of how vertical and how varied in topography each level is, unlocking a single upgrade can open up new paths in almost every area and often grant access to the game’s many secret levels.

Secrets are the lifeblood of Odallus, the reason it ends up being such a compelling platformer. Each level has four to six big ones, including life upgrades, bag upgrades for your subweapons (which are also used to uncover secrets!), new swords and armor, and exits to hidden levels. This is on top of all the hidden chests containing souls, which you trade to a skull-wearing fellow peddling spears and torches and soups. It’s worth mentioning, though, that hidden levels aren’t really optional here. There’s only four levels between you and the final boss but you need seven pieces of a gem to face him, one from each level boss and that includes the hidden ones. That means Odallus isn’t really a title for gamers who like to book it to the end, but it’s a dream for secret hunters and completionists.

Fans of dark fantasy will also find plenty to love here, especially in the enemy designs. A friend observed how close many of the foes look to the nightmarish monsters in Berserk, and they’re absolutely right. You’ll be facing all sorts of twisted creatures with hands coming out of their eyes and heads on writhing stalks and spines and needle-teeth everywhere. The blocky NES look is faithfully recreated with prominent color palettes for each level and enemy, and stiff but evocative animations. The sound design is nice and moody as well, and while I didn’t like the huge UI bars on the sides of the screen I soon got used to them, and found that the game is mostly designed with them in mind. And that’s the thing about Odallus, nothing was really left out of its design. It takes all the best parts of classic NES games, polishes them up with secrets and fair challenges, and gives you a huge game to explore and enjoy them in.

Story: 10/10
Odallus just hits right home when it comes to the story-telling of NES games. The plot is what you would expect, the characters are mostly one-note, but interesting because when you look past the grain, you can find so much more, and it knows how to use references (Highlander, Bladerunner, Earthworm Jim, etc.). 
From time to time, I found the choice of words weird but that just adds to the experience.

Graphics: 10/10
Very pleasing, good animated, it’s the old style done right.

Music: 7/10
While it has some good tunes, there are pieces that just get grating after a while, e.g. the water levels. On the other hand, the forest and final castle music are awesome.

Gameplay: 9/10
Good controls, versatility and when you got power ups you actually feel that you got a power up. Some enemies seem to be weak against certain sub weapons (e.g. fish men to spears) and with the lv3 armor, those sub weapons can even be charged up.

Initially, I gave this game a thumbs down though because of a bug that I reported. From what I've heard from the developers, they have tried for ages to fix this bug with the Aquaeducts level 1 boss (on Veteran mode) but seemingly got nowhere. Still, I got my answer and if you don't run into this bug, you should be able to finish the game (I did it by installing it on my other computer where it ran perfectly).

Overall this game is fun because it made me go after all the achievements, even the ones that are hard to get (like Speedrunner, Hunter, Highlander).

Boy, this really does feel as close as I'm going to get to a new classic style Castlevania game.

When it comes to nailing that NES era retro throwback style, Odallus does a whole lot right. Gameplay is tight and fun, difficulty is challanging but not insane, and there's a lot to explore, with hidden levels and secrets littered about to return to once your character has grown. The color palette looks strikingly old-school. There's just so much to like for those looking for a "classic feel" game. It also does an excellent job on that spooky horror atmosphere without actually being scary per say.

That's not to say it's all nostolga bait though, as a lot of the more frustrating things you'd expect from this sort of game has been trimmed out. Getting hit may knock you back but you won't be falling in instant death pits, and running out of lives only has you start from the beginning of the stage; a fitting punishment for failing I'd say when games from the era it imitates would often start you at the beginning of the game after enough deaths.

I think a lot of people know if this would be their sort of game or not just by seeing an old-school platformer in the images and to you I say yes, this game is as excellent as it looks.

I did a full video review at the game here if you're interested in hearing me ramble more about it: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QBuQwxWB6rE

Unlike most metroidvanias this game is level-based, but each level is filled with secrets and exploration so it doesn't become linear. There's also a secret passage in each main level sending you to a second level, which you'll need to find all of to beat the game. Some of the passages will require certain relics or secondary-weapons which you migt not always have for the current level you're at, which adds a similar kind of backtracking as other metroidvanias. 

The difficulty of the game is pretty average with a couple difficulty spikes (The snow boss and the two last bosses were the ones giving me most trouble). The bosses could be a little harder imo, but there is a veteran mode I didn't try yet which from the looks of it is quite different from normal mode too changing item placements, adding new puzzles and new areas.

The shop is the thing I didn't really like and ended up not really using either. You can buy health, ammo for sub-weapons and extra-lives and every time you buy something the price of the item you bought goes up. So I ended up just hoarding my orbs since buying things will just make the shop more expensive and you can get sub-weapons in the game pretty easily. As for extra-lives I don't feel it was necessary to put in the shop. I don't mind extra lives to be in the game since it works well with the checkpoint system (lose all lives and put back to the start of the area level, but lose one life and you're sent back to a checkpoint), but i personally didn't like the idea of buying 1-ups there when the game isnt very punishing with game overs.

Overall it's an enjoyable game and I highly recommend it at its current sale price!

Odallus: The Dark Call


Einer der besten, abgerundetsten 2D-Actionplatformer im klassischen Castlevania-Stil, den ich je gespielt habe, abgesehen von den unverwüstlichen Originalen aus der 8-bit bzw. 16-bit Ära. 

Ja, das Spiel ist als kristallklare Hommage hart und unerbittlich, und der hohe Schwierigkeitsgrad kann so manchen Gamer abschrecken, belohnt aber mit einer ansprechenden Ästhetik und gelungenen Spielmechanik. Ein besonderes Lob verdient neben dem einfallsreichen, stylischen Level- und Monsterdesign, und der butterweichen Steuerung die musikalische Untermalung und Soundkulisse. Hier wird eine düstere Atmospähre aufgebaut, die ich schon in Vergessenheit glaubte, und in ihrer Dichte phänomenal in den Spielablauf integriert ist.

Die Story, unser Recke Haggis zieht aus, um das Böse zu vernichten, reißt natürlich niemanden mehr vom Hocker, wartet aber mit einigen dezenten Überraschungen und Wendungen auf. Die Umsetzung ist fabelhaft: die vom Bösen befallene Welt, die von den alten Göttern verlassen wurde, ist insgesamt stimmig und hochwertig entworfen. Die Gegner sind mannigfaltig, die Bosse knackig, die Bewegungen für ein Spiel dieser Art flüssig animiert, das Kampfsystem ist ausgefeilt,  und die Lenkung der Spielfigur von haargenauer Präzision; so muss das sein! 

Den Vergleich zu Klassikern wie Castlevania, Ghost´n Goblins oder Demons Crest braucht dieses Spiele-Kleinod nicht zu scheuen, im Gegenteil: es hält ihren glanzvollen Geist mit Bravour aufrecht, und fügt spärlich neue Spielelemente- und mechaniken hinzu, ohne das Genre zu verwässern, oder zu sehr vom Wesentlichen abzulenken: der kurzweiligen Monsterhatz in einem glaubhaft überzeugenden Fantasyszenario.
     

Das Spiel ist exzellent, preiswert und gehört in jede seriöse Spielesammlung!

I'm a pretty big fan of the Castlevania series. They're generally a great blend of action, platforming, great music, and tons of weird monsters. The series has had far more hits than misses, and it's disappointing to me that Konami appears to be withdrawing from the video game market. Doing so will take Castlevania away from us forever, and we'll be left replaying those excellent classics and wishing we had something new. But the indie developers at Joymasher also apparently loved Castlevania, because Odallus: The Dark Call bears its influence proudly and it's magnificent.

Odallus is a neo-retro game; it's obviously a fully original game but its done in the style of games made 30 years ago. It's got the Ninja Gaiden style cutscenes, beautiful sprite based 2D graphics, and a chiptunes soundtrack. On my hard drive, it takes up 415MB so it's far beyond the storage capacity of an NES cartridge, but the look and feel is all there. It even occasionally has NES-style graphical glitches.

As Haggis, you find that your village is burning and your child is missing, so you strike out to fight demons and monsters and all sorts of nasty stuff and get him back. Haggis is armed with a sword, which isn't a chain whip, but it's perfectly satisfying when it comes to chopping up monsters. There are also subweapons that augment your fighting capacity. It mixes up the Castlevania formula by giving you a throwing axe that flies straight, a torch that burns like holy water, and a javelin that flies in an arc, and all three are readily available once you've found them. You'll often rely on those subweapons to do real damage, at least early in the game, because your starting sword is a little weak and slow.

Odallus also takes some influence from the Metroid series in that you can find relics that enhance your movement abilities, such as being able to breathe underwater and double-jump. The game is also full of secret areas, some of which require these relics to find. It's not a fully open map like Metroid, but it's broken down into levels that can revisited from the world map. Stuff like secret areas and multiple level exits are things that I loved about old NES games and they're done well.

Difficulty in the game is almost perfectly balanced. It's falls just on the right side of almost infuriating but still encouraging you to try again. Every time I ragequit on a boss (which happened once or twice), I'd jump back in after 10 minutes because I wanted to beat it and I knew I could. The final boss is absolutely brutal and I beat it with barely a sliver of life left, but it was so rewarding when I did.
 
I really don't have much to complain about here. The mine cart level kind of sucks a little, but it's nowhere near as frustrating as some classic counterparts. Odallus: The Dark Call is a must-play for Castlevania fans, or retro gaming enthusiasts. I've seen a lot of retro-ish games, but this is easily one of my favorites and one that gets it right.

[i]Va falloir arrêter de perdre son gosse à chaque fois..[/i]

[b]Odallus: The Dark Call[/b], sorti en 2015, est un Castlevania-like (donc plateforme 2D) où l'on incarne Haggis, un guerrier parti sauver son fils, enlevé par de cruels démons.

[h1]Les plus :[/h1]

- Difficile, mais pas injuste. Le jeu impose un skill assez élevé, parfois impose aussi de faire plusieurs fois le niveau, afin de passer un endroit afin de connaitre tous les timings, et les patterns des ennemis, mais les checkpoints sont généreux, surtout avant les boss.
- La bande-son est vraiment sympa. Musique 8bits réussie.
- Une bonne durée de vie, j'ai mis 14h à faire tout le jeu, sans trop fouiner pour récupérer tous les items, le jeu ayant usé de ma patience. (et ma manette)
- Graphiquement, c'est du pixel-art, un peu brouillon, mais ça va. Les décors sont variés, et ont une âme.
- Tout est question de loot et de recherche si l'on veut s'améliorer. Vous voulez plus de vie ? Cherchez la ! Vous voulez une meilleure arme/armure ? Pareil ! Ca pousse le joueur à fouiner dans tous les niveaux afin de débloquer un maximum d'avantages.
- Le gameplay (manette plus que recommandée !) est réussi. Sauter, frapper. Au fur et à mesure que vous avancez dans le jeu, vous débloquerez des équipements spéciaux qui vous permettront de pimenter vos parties, passer certains endroits inacessibles auparavant, etc... Ce qui rend le tout moins ennuyant. Vous disposez aussi d'armes de jet, afin de pouvoir attaquer à distance (d'où le nom "de jet"..)

[h1]Les moins :[/h1]

- Je suis passé totalement à côté de l'histoire. Insipide à mon goût.
- Musique réussie, mais qui ne change pas souvent.
- Pas de VF.
- Pas compatible avec le Steam Controller.

[h1]Conclusion :[/H1]

[b]Odallus: The Dark Call[/b] est un excellent jeu de plateformes, à classer tout de même dans la catégorie "Difficile", même si certains sont bien pires (je pense à Volgarr...).

34001500.review:
Rating: 9.5/10

Odallus is a story-driven platformer which pays homage the NES-era of Castlevania titles. JoyMasher builds upon the success of their last game, Oniken, and brings a level of much desired polish. It's not often you find a truly amazing throwback game such as Odallus here on Steam; however, this title definently defines everything desireable in a story-driven Metroidvania game!

I found there were things I both liked, and disliked, about Odallus; however, there were far more that I liked than disliked. Here are a few you should be aware of before buying:

+ Odallus sports an immersive story, it has a fully animated cinematic seen before you even reach the titlescreen, as well as a cutscene before you start the first level of the game. Each boss has ample dialog to keep the player entertained.
+ The player character has nice and fluid, tight controls.
+ Much like any Castlevania title, this game has a weapon system similar to Castlevania where you find weapons that act similar to powerups. 
+ Weapon usage is no longer convoluted and is bound to a single key, I'm looking at you Oniken.
+ Checkpoints!
+ Enemies drop currency which can be used at shops which are often located at points of interest in each level.
+ Branching paths in the level design offer rewards for exploration.

- Odallus, similar to JoyMasher's first game "Oniken", launches in their own launcher. This launcher offers features that should be handled in the in-game main menu.

Very good game in all aspects. Levels are big and fun to explore. There is a very light metroid element to it, where you can collect new powers and revisit old areas. 

It is, however, an old school game. It's not just the art style and basic mechanics, it's old school all the way. I personally find that a bit of a turn off, because we learned a lot about designing games in the last 30 years and a lot of common tropes back didn't age well in  my opinion. But I'm not judging the designer's choice here; there is an audience for this, for sure.

It's not as hard as other old school games. But enough to trigger a few rage quits, which for me is a problem; that's not the kind of experience I like in a game. I've had my fair share of those already.

I also have  a problem with the dash, an ability you find later on the game. The dash is triggered by double tapping the d-pad, like it used to be on many old games. If I didn't have more buttons on my controller/keyboard  I would take that as non-ideal but acceptable solution, but I do have more buttons. And ever since I got that ability I keep throwing myself at danger accidentally, because this is a platformer that requires a very agile dpad control! So I tap it constantly to adjust my trajectory and position. You can see how that's a problem. Then, of course, just to make me more frustrated, whenever I'm in an urgent situation and need to dash quickly, it doesn't work. Because of course not.

I do wish I'd see more games looking at the past for inspiration. There are many interesting things games used to do that is almost lost today. But I'd rather see some experimentation on top of that as well, rather than direct transposition just for nostalgia sake.

If direct transposition for nostalgia sake is what you're looking for, look no further. If this game were released 20 years ago it would have been my favorite game.

32276976.review:
Joymasher nails it again. Inspired by games such as Castlevania Odallus surpasses its inspirations. It is not a full fledged metroidvania but consists of a series of levels which are non-linear. Because of the non-linearity you will visit levels multiple times to uncover most paths.

At first sight it seems like a clone of Castlevania but once you play it feels different and has its own style and vibe to it. The story and style of the cutscenes borrows heavily from the anime Berserk, like taking on a desperate battle against a nightmarish army of demons.

There is a good variety of levels, like different environments and gameplay elements, level design is solid and the bosses are fun to beat. You start out as a slow moving clunky weak character and slowly transforms into a badass by finding hidden upgrades throughout the levels. The game gets better once you spend more time with it and builds up to a climax at the final boss fight which is epic.

There are, however, rough edges like screen tearing, big hitboxes, frequent framedrops and in particular the absence of a map which is a big miss for a semi-metroidvania, so it is far from perfect. Do not miss out on this title if you have any love for 8-bit retro styled games like, in particular, the NES entries of Castlevania.

32189115.review:
This is yet another review that goes under "I wish Steam had a "it's okay/Meh" button"

tl;dr This game is fine. However if you hate backtracking or games considered "Nintendo Hard" then I'd say skip.
In fact: It's hard for me to simply go "yes I recommend this"

By using your eyes you can see that Odallus: The Dark Call is trying to go for an NES styled game. It's not a game that's 1:1 with Castlevania; the game tries to do it's own thing by having a more nonlinear approach to progression. The main way to get through the game is by exploring to find powerups and upgrades. It's because of this design choice that you'll end up going through each stage mutiple times. 
I can see how backtracking through the eight main stages is seen as annoying, tedious, or "padding," Each level has secrets for the player to uncover, with each stage showing a counter of how many the player has found and how many are in the stage. And the game has both secrets not worth mentioning and 3 hidden secrets. Unfortunately there isn't a map or a proper checklist. It's because of this that it can get tiring to 100% the game.
Besides the secrets there is the issue with the levels themselves. Every level can be simply...boring honestly. The levels can standard forest level, standard water level, or standard slippery ice floor level. It really doesn't help that the OST for this game is boring and forgettable. None of the BGM ever tries to be exciting or fast paced. All the music is slow, repetitive, and uninspired.
Even with all that, this game can still be fun thanks to the tight controls. With all the upgrades found your character is really mobile. It definitely makes finding each secret feel worth. Also the combat is very simple; think of something more like Ninja Gaiden rather than Castlevania. Even if it's simple the game is still challenging enough to make you actually pay attention to not getting hit.

To recap
+Wonderful spritework and art
+Good controls
+Game lasts a good enough length
+-Challenging
+-Backtracking
+-Secrets required to finish the game
-Boring OST
-Your character's hitbox can be a little too big sometimes
-Levels can feel samey

32064030.review:
Let's go straight to the point, this is your go-to castlevania-style game on Steam.

Odallus clearly shines among the ridiculous number of attempts to recapture the spirit of good old NES games. There's an awesome catchy soundtrack all the way through, and the colorful design and choice of palette wonderfully manage to create this gloomy and yet badass atmosphere that is so typical of the Castlevania series.

The gameplay itself is even more awesome, though, for there are a few features from modern platformers that make the character more maneuverable than fellow Richter Belmont, while the gameplay keeps the rigidity and tight controls we learnt to love in this kind of games.

Difficulty-wise, it's what you should expect from a modern game that looks to feel like Castlevania. Normal mode might feel hard for those who are not that much into that kind of games, but it's still forgiving enough to not be a pain to beat.

On the other hand, Veteran mode (NG+) is some serious shit. The game is cleverly reworked to be harder, but not in a repetitive way. You get to see new enemies, to go through a new route, for areas and item locations are different, bosses have new patterns, and running out of lives does matter. Basically one of the best NG+ I've ever seen.

And did I mention the lore ? Oh come on, don't be shy, buy it !

30803784.review:
Estructural y morfológicamente se basa en parámetros propios de género Metroidvania, que son los que en teoría unifican, por medio de las dimensiones, distribuciones y localización de elementos, un mundo de juego que está categorizado o diversificado por zonas, en el cual el jugador tendrá libertad para escoger el camino que mejor vea en cualquier dirección, siempre que no haya algo que se lo impida.

Los Metroidvania tienen por costumbre formar un conjunto de caminos que están exentos de una orientación formal por los mismos, en su lugar son esquematizados de alguna forma para concluir una serie de puntos clave que habrá que localizar y que tendrán que ser solventados en el momento o con los objetos adecuados. Esto consigue formar un género propio para estar todo el dia parriba y pabajo, parriba y pabajo, parriba y pabajo...
La gran mayoría de los metroid suelen incluir teletransportes entre zonas para no frustar mucho al jugador, sin embargo tampoco se descuida en ningún momento el retroceso libre o en cualquier dirección por los mismos, siendo por norma general una jugabilidad ecuanime o paralela en el sentido de la dirección.

Odallus The Dark Call se plantea como un metroid de rasgos agudos en donde una prioridad en la expresión y su función connotan en una mezcla, que sin llegar a querer serlo, reune aspectos de otros juegos, técnicas de otros tiempos y globalidades en los géneros, para terminar siendo algo que es breve y simple pero completo y estable.

Unas 5 reliquias que ofrecen habilidades cruciales como lo es el doble salto, las armas y armaduras hasta nivel 3 que nos proporcionarán la fuerza y resistencia suficiente para los bosses, los corazones que mejoran los puntos de vida, unas páginas secretas con textos, y una ampliación de la mochila conformarán los aspectos localizables y libres por el mapa. Y aspectos más acumulutativos sin localización como lo son el dinero que ganamos al matar enemigos y la apertura de cofres con más dinero o armas secundarias se encarguarán del aguisantado.  Las armas secundarias se cuentan por 3 tipos que podremos acumular y alternar para cualquier molestia pero lo más destacable es su uso en algunos puzzles para acceder a objetos importantes. Tenemos un control simple de 3 botones,  más otro para alternar las armas a distancia secundarias.
El dinero servirá en las tiendas para comprar vida o armas secundarias. Las tiendas estarán puestas medio al tun tun, normalmente cerca de algún checkpoint.
La interfaz ofrecerá todos los datos del personaje o juego en la pantalla para evitar cualquier interacción fuera del control del personaje. El personaje estará aumentado, centralizado y seguido por la cámara en todo momento para entre estas dos cosas visuales lograr un enlace hacia su motor de juego que en este caso sería el control personaje.

Odallus: The Dark Call的复古，在形神两方面都达到了优秀水平。画面在秉承FC时代的粗糙像素和鲜艳配色的同时，已经尽可能兼顾了美感，如果你是个克苏鲁风格爱好者，部分场景和怪物造型甚至可以说是赏心悦目。操作手感较硬但是判定很精准，结合不低的难度和不多的存档点，要求玩家合理规划攻击和躲避的节奏而不是无脑砍砍砍。地图是开放的，但是遍布敌人和陷阱，能够畅快奔跑的地形很少，必须步步为营，因此直到通关之后我才意识到作为“类银河战士恶魔城”它的地图还是有些小，玩的时候却完全没注意到这一点。BOSS战继承了动作游戏最伟大而历久弥新的设计：分阶段的BOSS形态和程式化的BOSS攻击模式，讲真我要对发明这一点的游戏制作者前辈致以诚挚的敬意。年轻的游戏制作人啊，继续用BOSS战砸我吧，老朽还能再战二十年~

最后，就个人而言，本作还有一个加分项：整体上呈献了的古希腊神话的氛围。它的糙画面、硬手感、不断循环的悲怆音乐、上穷碧落下黄泉的艰苦追寻、孤身英雄挑战傲慢诸神的强烈反差，这一切与最终揭晓的残酷结局共同形成了教科书式的希腊悲剧精神内核——英雄在与命运抗争的过程中遭遇注定的失败。俄狄浦斯，你杀了你爹！[spoiler] 奥达勒斯，你杀了你儿！（我瞎说的，主角并不叫奥达勒斯）[/spoiler]这一点或许只是游戏制作者的无心插柳，或者我个人的通感太强。不过复古的游戏风格在表达古典内容时总归比表达未来内容时更贴切，也更能够接受时间的考验，想想那些8比特的机甲和上世纪中叶的科幻电影吧。

总评：８/10

It's clearly trying to be Castlevania (esp. 2) but it misses the mark. The pixelated graphics, low framerate, and really chunky hitboxes combine to feel more like a sequel to Astynax. Not a bad thing, exactly, but a smoother experience would have been better.

So far it's been quite fun, but there are some notable annoyances. Screen/sprite tearing and a really low framerate are unattractive, but mostly just aesthetics. 

Some of the platforms, such as in the "secret" waterfall level muck with your ability to leap in a manner that's not just difficult, it's also not fun. (You have to adjust your timing by jumping and landing so you CAN jump immediately to the next platform... or simply by lucking out. This is an annoying thing that should have been polished out in testing, IMO. Feels and looks like a bug.)

Tone is good and the story reminds me of Demon's Crest, which is a very good thing.

Keyboard controls are pretty awkward. You probably ought to avoid that headache and use a gamepad.

Fun as is. Seems a gem in the rough, in that it would really shine with some polish.


Update: Played it on a higher-end system with a game-pad and many of the flaws reduced or vanished, from the interrupted jumping to an improved framerate and tearing.

30054476.review:
(Gameplay stats are wrong because I had trouble getting the game to launch through steam. I have probably 5-6 hours in it.)

Action game inspired by NES classics like Castlevania that takes its slavish devotion a little too far, with graphics that would be called terrible if not for the retro connection, music that deserves that term regardless, a reversion to the bad old days of save points miles away from difficult boss fights, and errors like enemy pop-in and dodgy hitboxes that might be excusable on low-end hardware but not here. This is a NES game that requires a 400MB download.

It's a sort-of Metroidvania, "sort-of" because there are multiple independent levels, not one interconnected world, but with the same sort of backtracking/area locking where finding double-jump boots (or whatever) allows reaching a new exit. That's all fine, but it's a minor quibble that it's done much less obviously than most Metroidvania-style games. On first playthrough it's easy to assume that levels with "secret" entrances are optional, when in fact they are required for completion and for the optimal order of play. One of the first secret levels provides a crucial underwater breathing item, for example, which is required for just about every other unlock, like the critical armour and weapon buffs.

By far the best reason to play is the grim aesthetic, which owes a huge debt to "Berserk". The plot is far darker than Nintendo would have ever allowed and the monsters are all twisted, uncanny-valley things of human faces on bulging flesh-tentacles. If you have fond memories of Castlevania and want to try a new version with art direction by H.R. Giger and a plot then it's worth a whirl, but ultimately I think it's challenging for the wrong reasons.

Despite the gripes, nothing about Odallus (on normal difficulty) is actually that hard other than perhaps the bosses. I'm just not convinced it's fun, either, since the challenge is mostly from cheap deaths, tedious memorization of boss patterns etc.

30043826.review:
I have mixed feeling about Odallus. It wears its influences on its sleeve a bit too much in my opinion, and I find the specific callouts to NES games of yore a bit cloying, really. That's because the game is best when its original, and I wish it struck out on its own path a little more. There are times it doesn't seem to know what it wants to be- a modern take on a classic formula or an authentic late 80s-styled game, and so as a result stumbles a bit in both. 

I also found it too hard in an unfun way. The levels, enemies and bosses are challenging but generally fair. But the non-linear approach is galling because it really IS linear, and if you do things in the wrong order its incredibly difficult. I had to look at a suggested stage order after I got tired of dying over and over trying to figure out what to do next.

I still recommend it though, because there are definite flashes of brilliance and the moment to moment exploration and combat is very satisfying. It was clearly made with love by talented designers, and I hope in their next game they trust their instincts more and lean on nostalgia less.

Je ne recommande pas ce jeu. Je le trouve frustrant, difficile et je n'ai même pas de plaisir à y jouer. 

Avant qu'on me dise que ce genre de jeu, ce n'est pas pour des mauviettes, sachez que j'ai terminé à 100% le jeu Castle in the Darkness. En ce qui concerne Odallus, la difficulté est une insulte. Quand on meurt, on perd une vie et quand on n'a plus de vie, il faut recommencer le niveau au complet. Ce n'est pas du tout plaisant quand on se trouvait devant un boss difficile. Je sais, je sais, c'était comme ça avant. Le bon vieux temps où on avait du temps à perdre. Certains s'en ennuient. Pas moi. 

En plus, dans un vieux jeu, c'était comme ça aussi, mais au moins, on recommençait avec des vies. On pouvait également utiliser des mots de passe. Donc quand on faisait le même niveau une deuxième fois, c'était avec la même difficulté. Mais dans Odallus, en ce qui concerne les vies, il faut les acheter. Et savez-vous quoi? À chaque fois qu'on en paie une, le prix augmente. C'est également le cas pour tous les objets. Donc potentiellement, on peut se retrouver bloqué parce qu'on a trop eu de difficulté. Tout ça pour augmenter artificiellement la durée du jeu, j'imagine...

Parlant de difficulté, n'oublions pas les ennemis qui nous foncent dessus à pleine vitesse malgré le fait qu'on les frappe, nous faisant inévitablement des dégâts. Pensons également à ceux qui nous lancent des projectiles et qui, sur notre chemin obligatoire, sont placés à un endroit où, pour les atteindre, il sera presque impossible de ne pas prendre de dégâts avec le contrôle maladroit qu'on a avec notre personnage.

Bref, pour toutes ces raisons, je ne crois pas qu'Odallus est un si bon jeu.

¿Eres un amante de los gráficos EGA donde los scanlines y el glow de los antiguos monitores CRT aportaban el resto de la magia a esos gráficos?, Este es tu juego, aunque aspirante a pseudo juego de 8 bits, realmente nos encontramos ante un juego en el que el tamaño de los sprites, degradados, fondos y todo tipo de detalles están cuidados con mucho gusto y amor retro que a día de hoy sólo puedes disfrutar con emuladores.

Odallus tiene una jugabilidad muy conseguida, no tendrás esos problemas midiendo el salto para caer a un pozo, no es un MegaMan, los enemigos son asequibles, ni fáciles a rabiar pero tampoco imposibles.

Todos los juegos que ha creado esta compañía se nota que están hechos por fans de una época especial para todo aquellos que vivieron la magia de finales de los 80 y principios de los años 90.

El juego se mueve muy fluido, no tiene frameskip que tan de moda estaba por aquella epoca en los ordenadore de 8 bits, de hecho funciona en unos perfectos 60fps, no es que el juego requiera esa tasa de fps, pero sí que le da un empaque que junto con los shaders utilizados para emular los mejores CRT de la época le dan el sabor retro definitivo.

La pena es que no compartan el shader utilizado para el juego, ya que tiene lo mejor en cuanto a representación de un buen CRT, scanlines, glow, halation, gaus...

Lo dicho, si eres un treintañero con ganas de revivir un buen plataformas, este es tu juego.

Le doy un 9 por el gusto de sus desarrolladores al crear el juego, no le doy un 10 porque la traducción la ha tenido que hacer un compañero de forma desinteresada al que le estoy agradecido.

Adictivo.

Un plataformas como dios manda.

29437973.review:
Odallus is a fantastic homage to the NES. It plays great, looks great and sounds great. There's a fair bit of backtracking through levels, but since all the secrets and hidden paths have a tell, you're never stuck looking for an invisible staircase.

Story is minimal and mostly presented in the form of hidden runes, ingame text and cutscenes. While there is some amazing artwork in these cutscenes, the story itself never rises above the average . However, the gameplay certainly does.  Exploring the levels and finding the secrets is fun, while the combat and platforming is tight. The finite amount of lives may let you think that the game is going to be extremely harsh, but the opposite is true. Whenever you open a door it stays open. Once you run out of lives, you continue with 3 new lives and keep your progress. It's a nice reminder of how harsh the NES era could be, while making sure that we don't have to endure those harsh rules in 2017. 

All in all, a very cool game with great level design and memorable bossfights.

29135652.review:
[h1]Beautifully-executed retro action platformer.[/h1]

[i]Odallus: The Dark Call[/i] checks all the right boxes (including being "wrong" in just the right ways), with crisp controls, inspired level design, and beautifully-grotesque pixel art style and chip-tune soundtrack inspired by the best NES classics like [i]Castlevania[/i], [i]Metroid[/i], [i]Ghosts 'n' Goblins[/i], and [i]Ninja Gaiden[/i].

The game opens with the brief backstory Haggis, the retired-warrior-turned-hunter, who one night has his hunt disturbed by the sounds of battle raging back in his village. Worried for his son, he rushes home to find the town ablaze, set upon by horrific demons, and his son missing. Enraged, Haggis embarks on a final, desperate quest to rescue his son and uncover the mysterious motivations of, and ultimately defeat, the dark forces who have invaded the land.

Using a reliable input device like the XBox One controller, the gameplay is crisp, quick, and responsive. The combat and platforming elements are challenging - at times, even a little frustrating - but never feel cheap or contrived. The well-balanced difficulty curve and thoughtfully-distributed progress saves and powerups ensure that when you die - and you WILL die - you'll feel compelled to jump back in to get just a little farther, to give that tricky boss one more go, to find that next secret. Odallus is hard work at times, but the experience is rewarding and fun.

Immediately upon starting the game, fans of old-school action platformers will be impressed by the cohesive art style and fantastic, if simple, controls, but will soon discover that the real star is the near-perfectly-executed level design. Each of the unique stages features a diverse cast of enemies, difficult (and often disgusting) bosses, and intense platforming sections. Each stage also introduces new gameplay mechanics, granting Haggis new skills and powers. Returning to a beaten level armed with your recently-acquired double jump or water-breathing ability allows you to reach previously-inaccessible areas containing powerups which enable you to progress even further, or grant entry to hidden stages filled with their own rewards and perils.

While [i]Odallus: The Dark Call[/i] is undoubtedly an homage to the console and arcade classics of yore (right down to some suitably-cheesy dialogue), nearly all of which saw their heydey before the birth of your average Steam gamer, its outright charm and obvious quality of vision and execution propell it well beyond mere fan service or mimicry. If this game had been released as an NES cartridge in 1988, it would have been a smash hit of the kind that spawns franchises, but in spite of that, this is a [b]good[/b] game regardless of one's appreciation for its vintage aesthetic.

Highly recommended.

Odallus is a Metroidvania action platformer that borrows a lot of gameplay aspects from the NES classics such as Castlevania, Metroid and Zelda II.  And where so many indie games have failed, Odallus does a decent job of carrying the old formula and at the same time feeling like bringing something new on the table.

You play as Haggis, en Ex Soldier and now a hunter who has lost his wife.The war is over and now he lives a peaceful life with his son. One night when he left the village to go for hunting demonic-like creatures evaded his village and kidnapped his son. Now he is set on to find his son back and take revenge for pillaging his village. 

The graphics are 8 bit style and it is so NES alike they even went with a NES color pallet. You are presented the story through dialog and through some artifacts that you discover throughout the game. The background graphics however are more detailed and look more 16 bit. Personally I would prefer it, if they had made a 16 bit design but I understand what the developer was aiming for. The music is decent, -more on the depressing side, which I think fits the serious tone of the game. Everything else that evolves presentation is simplistic, like the Map, the inventory, the dialogs etc.

The gameplay will be familiar to those who have played retro action platformers. While it is very simplistic it takes some time to get used to the controls etc. There are the classic mechanics - most of them you acquire as upgrades as you progress- like double jumping, dashing, secondary attacks, armor upgrades and more. The game overall might not offer a lot of replay ability since it is very straightforward but it gets very addicting when you start getting the achievements. 

Some things I didn’t like are first of all difference in difficulty in some areas. It gets really hard in some stages and a piece of cake in others. Also the bosses are very creative from a design perspective but you can beat most of them by just taking the damage and spam attack their weak points. The last boss however is one of the hardest ones I have ever played and a very memorable in my opinion. Some other minor things like the attempt to make funny dialog while the game is super serious doesn’t make sense as well. 

All in all, I really enjoyed my time with Odallus, the exploration, the tight controls, the overall dark theme and the hunt for achievements make an addicting package that anyone who likes those types of games should give it a shot. Some go as far as calling it a hidden gem and I don’t disagree at all with that statement.

I really appreciate what the developers were trying to do with this game. They don't really make these Gargoyle's Quest-style games anymore -- games that are similar to the Metroid style because of the gradual acquisition of power-ups that open new pathways, but it plays more like an action game, with limited lives and checkpoints and separate stages instead of one huge interconnected world. It's nice to go back to that.

But sheesh, Odallus is not very fun to play, and most of that displeasure comes from the combat. I groan internally when combat situations come up (and they come up a lot), because I really don't want to have to suffer through another awkward fight.

I don't want to deal with enemies that are the exact right height that my sword slashes go right over their head. Or maybe they're one pixel too far away from the tip of my sword to hit them, despite it looking like the strike connected. Or maybe I [i]did[/i] actually hit them, but the feedback is so subdued that I didn't realize I landed the attack.

I hate having to deal with enemies on awkward ledges that require me to waste my scarce projectile ammo to have a chance of cleanly damaging them; otherwise, I've got to jump up at them and usually get hit during my climbing-up animation, or leap down at them and hope they don't smack me first, since I have no downward strike to give me the initiative. Even Firebrand from Gargoyle's Quest could at least cling to walls or hover and shoot fire from a distance to give him the advantage, but no such luck here.

And did I mention the enemies tend to not get stunned from attacks at all? And a lot of those enemies are pretty quick. So while you're desperately trying to chop their face off, they'll probably just barrel straight through your attack and straight through your body too. I eventually tried to avoid enemies whenever possible, though you usually can't since they're often blocking your path.

Even ignoring the combat, you've got these surprisingly large levels with multiple routes and secret areas, but no map to speak of in order to assist navigation. Did you get looped back around to an area you've already been to, or is this a new location that merely [i]looks[/i] like a previous one? Where was that blocked-off route that you couldn't enter before because you didn't have the right item? Have fun trying to find out.

And while you're doing that, you get to enjoy a bunch of absolutely insipid music. Not bad enough to make your ears bleed, but still repetitive and uninspired enough to quickly become grating.

Oh well. If nothing else, getting the DLC and playing as a pantsless gargoyle was fun for a bit. XD

Game Score: 8/10

Odallus: The Dark Call was a wonderful platformer. It took about 4.5 hours to beat the game and find almost all of the secrets. Great controls and a couple different weapons that always had a use at some point which made finding them and keeping stocked up worth the effort. There were plenty of puzzle / maze aspects that will keep you searching for the next armour or weapon upgrade, both of which are incredibly important for beating the last boss. (He's tough!)

Most of the boss battles were a challenge, but most of the challenge came from learning their patterns. Once you got that figured out it was a good ol' fashion smack down! Each stage has it's own difficulties which can be overcome by finding items that give you the ability to double jump, float, or dash. It's never easy though because near the end stages you are bombarded by enemies and spike traps.

Pros:
- Stage selection screen. I've always been a sucker for an overworld map.
- Challenging, but not impossible
- Responsive controls
- Puzzles make you think but aren't over done
- I never felt lost

Cons:
- Items cost progressively more the more you buy (the price caps eventually though). I found this kind of annoying because generally it was never a struggle to have enough money to buy things. Although, there were times where I used up all my money on extra lives and didn't have money to buy spears to get through a secret passage. This meant I would have to go back to early levels to grind for money. This didn't add any challenge to the game, it just increased the amount of time you run through already completed stages, which wasn't that fun.
- The float button is the same as jump, so when you get double jump and float, you have to double jump before you float which is frustrating on some levels with spikes on the roof. I didn't explain that well but once you get to that point you'll know.

I really don't have anything terribly bad to say about Odallus. As you can see, my cons were pretty specific nit picky stuff and not devestating game flaws. I would totally recommend this to anybody who enjoys metroidvania style games. Maybe $10 is too high of a price for some, but this game goes on sale often so I say pick it up!

28550892.review:
If you're looking for something that would remind you of Castlevania, look no further. Odallus is a pretty good platformer that takes inspiration from the famous classic horror series, but still stands on its own.

It plays like older NES games, even going as far as to include life counter, yet with the inclusion of the world map, it also offers a Metroidvania experience. First and foremost, however, it's still a platformer. Just with a couple of side-paths and power ups. Don't expect it to rival actual Metroidvania games in that aspect.

I should probably mention right away that lives won't bother you much. There are shortcuts that you activate within levels that will always stay open, and Game Overs only put you back to the beginning of the level/world map. It's definitely one of the less-obtrusive live systems in any game.

The gameplay and controls are tight, and, thankfully, also don't emulate worst part of older games. You're always in control, and if you fall down a pit, it's always your fault. 

Level design is not bad, but there are a few annoying gimmicks along the way. They're all really small, and Metroidvania aspect helps with that a lot. For example, there is one really annoying boss that comes to mind, but you can open up a level where you can get a Level 3 sword before fighting him, and make him a non-issue.

The game's relatively easy if you've played many platformers, but it will provide enough challenge to keep you entertained. Took me about 6 hours to beat, and that's just the normal difficulty setting. There's also a harder one, which promises new item placements, among other things, but from what I've seen, it's quite annoying. The first level had randomly spawning enemies on bosses, which isn't a good sign.

One thing that felt weird was the shop system. Throughout the game you find shops where you can buy weapon ammo, lives and health items. Once you buy any of the items, the price for that item rises. Considering that sometimes you need items to solve puzzles, it's a weird decision. If you're not good at the game and, for example, keep losing to a boss, I can see it leading to grinding money, which is just bad. Consider this your PSA: do not buy items unless absolutely needed. Restocking on, say, 2 axes you've wasted on every opportunity to do so will probably lead to grinding.

The only thing that I really didn't enjoy were a LOT of bugs I encountered. One boss' attack was broken, text box that displayed lines of code, what seemed to be broken AI in some places, and plethora of smaller issues that weren't really major, but definitely annoyed me. Still, nothing gamebreaking.

In short, if you're looking for a pretty good retro platformer with a great atmosphere, get it.

Well polished action-platformer that successfully creates a dark and foreboding world.  

The story is interesting but intentionally ambiguous/confusing.  There are a wide variety of excellent sprites and levels made in a style reminescent of old Castlevania games.  The music fits well with the dark atmosphere and retro style.  

The gameplay is very good.  Movement and combat feels tight and balanced.  Subweapons provide combat variety as well as exploration and puzzle-solving tools.  The many secrets and powerups provide bonuses to those who take the time to explore and revisit old levels.  Some provide additional movement capabilities that benefit both exploration and combat.  Interestingly, all of them seem to be optional, so one could play Odallus either linearly or Metroidvania-style.

The game wasn't very difficult until the final boss.  There aren't any insta-death spots in the game, and almost every challenge can be overcome by precise movements and attacks.  I never felt that any particular section was unfair (except maybe the minecart portions in an optional level).  There is a hard mode for players who like additional challenge.

Overall, I very much enjoyed this game.  I highly recommend it to Castlevania fans, retro gamers, or general fans of action-platformers.

27471734.review:
This has quickly become one of my all time favourite games. The art and music are excellent and the gameplay is some of the best I have found in this genre. This game is definitely worth a look, particularly if you have an interest in retro platformers - Odallus feels every bit as memorable as the old games that inspired it.

A key element of gameplay is exploration. Many important items, including those which are needed to progress to new areas are hidden across the game. Finding new levels and secrets will often require returning to previous levels after acquiring new abilities. Odallus demands more exploration and secret-finding than most games. I ran into a bit of frustration in my first playthrough when I didn't know where to go, but in the end I am glad to have eventually discovered everything without needing to look up a guide.

The difficulty of this game is very well thought out. There are no cheap tricks or instant deaths. Bottomless pits are rare and when you do happen to fall into one you are returned to your original location with only a small penalty to your hitpoints. Dying in this game is usually the result of being worn down over time, rather than sudden, unavoidable damage. If you are having trouble in a level, you can often explore elsewhere and find something to tip the balance in your favour. Combat is uncomplicated and effective, and you have plenty of weapons and abilities at your disposal. The real challenges are often found in enemy and boss encounters. Well balanced difficulty, great combat and open ended gameplay make Odallus a definite advance over the usual platformer formula.

I enjoyed Joymasher's previous title Oniken a lot, and Odallus shows immense improvement in terms of presentation, pixel art quality, level design and gameplay. The music is evocative and complements the unique feel of each area - 'Gael's Castle' is one of my favourite chiptune tracks. The attention to detail in the art and design of each level makes this game feel like a real adventure. Once you have discovered where everything is, Veteran Mode gives you another opportunity to play without knowing all the secrets and enemy locations - definitely one of the best implementations of a harder difficulty/new game plus mode. It would be fantastic to see this game get more attention, I strongly recommend giving it a look.

FIRST NOTE: This game is not a Metroidvania. It is a series of levels that have some minor amount of secrets, exploration, and branching paths. But it is NOT a singular, connected, big, nonlinear map. SIDE NOTE: There IS back-tracking, but the upgrades aren't that overpowered. In stuff like Symphony of the Night and Guacamelee your upgrades kind of break the game (like Poison Mist Form or Goat Fly) when brought to the earlier sections, and that makes back-tracking fun rather than a chore.

Definitely sticks to its guns on being retro. I really hate to give this a thumbs down. I think the people who made this game really did a great job. I might have enjoyed playing this game, but I ran out of lives on level 4. The funny thing is, you can grind money to buy extra lives. And that's what I did to get through some sticky situations. However, the vendor before the boss that killed me didn't sell extra lives that time. So I hit retry. That sent me back to the beginning of the level. Mind you, this game has two difficulties and I chose the easier one.

Sorry, I grew up with these kind of games. Personally, I'm not nostalgic for this stuff. I'm spoiled by modern games that have checkpoints and what amounts to "infinite lives" by these old standards. When I do play old NES or SNES games on an emulator, you better believe I abuse save states. I just don't have the patience for this stuff any more.

So for me it all comes down to the fact that it needed something other than difficulty to offer. Like an intriguing story or truly Metroidvania-style, rewarding exploration.

***
EDIT: Removed some inflammatory wording, added extra words for what I want from the game. I've also found that my point on difficulty needed some further elaboration. Because I have played games that are as hard or harder, and I should lay out the difference between difficulty that is fun and satisfying and what makes this game frustrating and annoying.

I mentioned the lives system already, but let me get into why this and how it affects the game is a problem. I'll use Symphony of the Night as an example (since that is the definitive Metroidvania anyway). That game doesn't have lives. When you die, you immediately game over and have to reload your last checkpoint. That sounds harder, so why does Odallus come across as so much more difficult?

When you die in Odallus, you do NOT get back anything you spent during that life. On top of that, each subweapon has its own ammo. There are no candlesticks to break open, enemies do not drop anything but money (I think). The only ways to get more ammo are to go back to specific areas where they spawn or to buy them from a vendor. And every time you buy something from a vendor, that item becomes more expensive for the next purchase. On top of that, the vendor will remember these prices when you die and when you continue. This means that it's possible to put the game into a potentially unwinnable state. Or, at least, to a point where getting more lives means a mountain of grinding. At that point, it's potentially better to restart the game!

A lot of old games felt like this. You pretty much had to play again and again to figure out the best way to do EVERYTHING so that you could THEN get from beginning to end in (essentially) one swoop. But do you know what old games also had? Passwords. Yeah. Not only did these serve as a means to continue when saving wasn't a possibility due to hardware limitations, but many games also gave the player a means of catching up when using a password. For example, in Castlevania you can quickly get back your upgraded whip just by breaking a few candlesticks. And in Mega Man, the password system included weapon unlocks and other power ups.

26593310.review:
Odallus: The Dark Call is a retro metroidvania where you play a father in search of his son who was kidnapped by an evil cult looking to summon old gods and reclaim the world that was once theirs. This game is a real labor of love and you can tell that the team spent a lot of time trying to get all the little details of what made older console platformers great. 

Visually, Odallus is stunning despite being so simplistic. The color palette is dark but not obnoxiously so and enemies look like they fit into the environment they’re in. The screen even has a decent scanlines filter and the edges are distorted as-if you were viewing the game on an old curved CRT monitor. The music and sfx are great too and have the feel of an old sega game, especially the low fidelity voice clips sporadically mixed in.

Odallus also has its fair share of nostalgia thrown in, but it’s not done in an in-your-face “DOES ANYONE REMEMBER THIS?” kind of way like how other games do it. Subtle things like a mother-brain themed boss and a half-finished quote by the merchant are scattered about just enough to be interesting without turning into a reference-fest.

Gameplay is another part where Odallus shines. Controls are snappy and responsive, save for a few ledge-grabbing issues, and the precision makes combat fun and intuitive. The majority of secrets are sensibly hidden just well enough to make you work for them but still giving you a sense of satisfaction for having figured them out. Most bosses are fair, with a few exceptions, and have their distinct patterns that you can study until you are able to beat them without taking a single hit. Later on though, you will need to upgrade your weapons and armor as the difficulty curve takes a massive spike in the final areas. 

This game is, of course, not without its setbacks. The shop system is fairly nonsensical in that as you buy an item, its price increases. I guess they didn’t want players farming items to make certain parts of the game easier but if that’s the case, why did they put a ceiling on the item cost? The extra lives mechanic is also fairly pointless as you can just continue indefinitely and all the lives do is give you the ability to respawn at a checkpoint instead of the beginning of the level. Bosses and minibosses defeated during your previous life stay dead and game switches thrown stay thrown (e.x. doors unlocked/portals opened). So it’s kind of silly to even have the lives in the first place but that’s a really minor issue IMO.

So the question you’re probably asking yourself is: Is Odallus: The Dark Call worth the buy? If you like frustratingly hard but fun games that beat you until you beat them back followed by a triumphant fist pump, then I think you already know the answer.

26513489.review:
Odallus is a solid metroidvania style game that provides a good challenge for people who enjoy games that ask the player to use skill and get better.

The game isn't hard to learn.  You start out being able to jump and swing a sword.  As time goes by, you'll gain more abilities/upgrades such as sub-weapons, floating, extra hit points, better armor, etc.  Enemies occasionally drop orbs which act as money that you can spend at shops located on stages to get more subweapons/hit points/extra lives.  Stages also have chests lying around which will give you sub-weapons, life, or orbs.  There are 9 stages to complete, usually with a couple secrets, a mini-boss guarding some sort of upgrade and a main boss guarding part of the crystal.  There are 5 stages on the surface that go in a linear order, but each of the first four surface stages has an alternate exit that leads to an underground stage.  Certain stages and secrets can only be gotten to by acquiring upgrades from other stages.  Upon completing a stage or deciding to leave a stage, you can choose where you would like to go.  The stage selection screen gives you information on whether you've beaten the final boss of the stage as well as the number of secrets you still haven't found.  You'll start with 3 lives.  If you die, you'll spawn with full life at the last checkpoint you activated.  If you run out of lives, you'll restart at the beginning of the stage you're on with 3 lives again.  On veteran mode you lose all of your orbs if you run out of lives, not sure if this happens on normal or not.

It's hard to comment much on the difficulty since I used the cheat code to activate veteran mode from the start, so I never played through on the normal difficulty.  The game is fairly challenging and you need to get better at it in order to complete it, so don't expect to just breeze through it like many games nowadays.  You start with 4 hearts of health and can get up to 8 total from upgrades.  Enemies do anywhere from 1/4th of a heart worth of damage up to 1 ½ (Usually bosses).  While you can recover health during stages at shops or from chests, you can't carry health items with you, so don't expect that crutch to get you through boss fights.  Most enemies are fair, with an occasional annoying enemy here or there, learn their patterns and you shouldn't have many issues with them.  Bosses work much the same, learn their patterns and exploit them.  Some stages have environmental hazards that make them more difficult to navigate through.  There is a little artificial difficulty in the game, but it doesn't occur very often, and rarely results in your death.  Took me around 8-10 hours to complete the game 100% on veteran mode.  I died plenty of times, but those deaths usually occur while learning areas, enemies, and bosses.

There's a bit of story in the game, but nothing deep.  It's mainly there to give your character an excuse to be there.  Characters aren't really explored either.  Music and sound are both fine.

A couple of complaints about the game, none of them very big deals, but resulting in an occasional annoyance or frustration.  1.  While the controls are usually fine, there are moments where they seem insufficient.  There were occasional times where the game would ignore my inputs, usually when I tried to do two things at once such as turn & attack (resulting in me turning but just standing there instead of attacking) or float & use a subweapon (resulting in me not using my subweapon).  2.  Grabbing onto ledges is an automatic ability in the game.  Some enemies can be placed close to a ledge, so you can jump up meaning to hit them and drop back down to safety but grab onto the ledge accidentally instead and take a hit.  3.  The game has no map, which means if you revisit stages to get all the secrets, you need to remember the whole stage or re-explore the whole stage.  4.  Usually enemies do not respawn unless you travel a certain distance from them and come back, but some enemies will respawn once you leave the screen.  Had an occasional issue with an underwater enemy that would respawn below me when I would double jump to see what was up above me.  Was pretty much unavoidable taking damage upon coming back down.  5.  The game has a couple bugs as well.  Got a bug where an enemy pillar tried to create 4 separate ice shards to throw at me, instead the game freaked out and about 100 of the shards appeared on the screen flying all over the place and kept re-appearing.  I killed the enemy quick and the shards all froze on the screen and would hurt me if I touched them, but I was able to cut through them and get out of there.  Found another bug on the mine cart level.  Completed a mine cart section, but eventually took a path back to the beginning of the same exact mine cart section to get a secret.  The mine cart was kind of phased out but I tried jumping in it and it wouldn't move and I became permanently stuck inside of it.  Had to open the menu and exit the stage and come back in from the start.

Enjoyed the challenge of playing through this.  It's a good game.

If, like me, you were old enough to play NES games back in the late 80s, you'll clearly recognize this game as having that visual and musical aesthetic...(oh cool!) but also 80s-style gameplay and controls (aaaaand they just lost me). Do you actually remember gaming in the late 80s? Like seriously? There was nothing better at the time because it did not exist yet. Was a game in the 80s torturously difficult with controls that make you want to throw your controller into the wall so hard that it sticks in like a shuriken? 

Sucks to be you, because adjusted for inflation to 2013, games in the late 1980s on NES cost $89 before tax, so unless you or your parents were loaded, buying another game was not feasible. I only recall my parents ever getting me 3 rentals on NES (Mickey's Mouse Capades, Zelda II (SCREW that game), and Super Mario Bros 3), so renting another game obviously wasn't something some kids could do, either. Those games that pissed us off as kids? Well, many of us were stuck with them and couldn't get more for a long time, if at all, so we just "made due." We played the games for hours upon hours, trying to beat them and either never succeeding, or finally winning and realizing the "trip" to that victory was so miserable that it wasn't worth it.

Today, however? Whether you're a kid or an adult, there are so many more video games now than back then, obviously, so you have choices. Your average parent, who says "Fine, I'll buy you one sixty dollar game this year," would agree to buy their kid 12 games for $60 cumulatively, becasue it's so much more value and less risk of the kid not liking it. With Steam, you can ACTUALLY get 12 for $60 on sale. Heck, you can get a lot more than that if you stick to the $0.99 games on sale, but quality will be of diminishing value, most of the time. Not only do you more games to choose from, but there are more advanced games to choose from. 

Genres and mixes of genres are around today that were not around in the 80s, controls have been made slicker and more responsive. Want a 2D Metroidvania with great controls, fun gameplay, beautiful artwork, and an okay story? Then play Dust: An Elysian Tale. So many other alternatives other people could probably suggest that Odallus: The Dark Call, but sheer nostalgia alone does not a great game make. I could ramble on, but let's get to talking specifically about this one game.

Music and visuals: The game looks and sounds like an NES game. Fine by me! It doesn't detract from me having fun. No complaints and I actually really like the visuals and the music here. Good stuff!

Story: What I've seen thus far is nothing interesting or impressive, but there's more than your average NES-era Castlevania game, as best as I can tell. It seems pretty "throw-away" thus far.

Controls: They could make the game control smoothly, but they deliberately chose not to. There is no true benefit to crappy NES-quality control. Will I get nostalgic because I remember back when games used to piss me off because movements were clunky? No, I'll just be pissed off. The world has freaking VR headsets and motion controls now, so it's not too much to ask for controls that feel good in a type of game that has been around for 30-ish years.

Gameplay: Although the controls are part of this, there are things aside from that which are an issue. As in the 80s, enemies will typically respawn on the edge of the screen if you leave that part of the screen and go back to it. When you're playing in areas with lots of places you can fall, missing multiple platforms on the way down, resulting in at least a one-minute trek back up, assuming you don't fall again due to a missed jump, all the enemies that whittled your health down in an already-challenging game, are whittling your health down even more along the way. It gets very old and annoying trying to get throgh certain areas just to reach a boss, and you can die before reaching that boss without making any sort of progress that can help you to do better the next time you try.

Continuing on from that, though there are checkpoints in the levels, if you lose all your lives, you have to start the entire level over. Money only seems to matter for buying a couple of extra lives here and there, and if a boss is absolutely wrecking you, you're going to have to start the level over, meaning your odds of beating the boss this time are even lower than when you were attempting back-to-back runs on the boss from a few rooms away, because now you've had time away from the boss and fall out of the groove of battling it. Unlike a game like Dark Souls, you can't just go grind for upgrades to be more powerful than the first time you tried the bosses, either, so misery, misery, annoyance, annoyance.

In short, this game is only for the following: 1. people who value nostalgia at the expense of the actual positive changes that have come to video gaming since the 80s and early 90s, as well as 2. masochists who just want to lose constantly because difficult just equals fun to them so the more aggravating and punishing the game is, the better, and 3. braggarts who just want to dedicate too much time to completing the game so they can brag about doing so, thus stroking their egos in the process. If these sound like you, then you'll probably love it! This game's really abusive, difficult, and insulting in that it didn't bother to update what was worth updating with the times. 

If you don't fall into any of those three camps of people, it is highly unlikely that you will enjoy this game. I believe that most people who play games fall into one of those three categories, so most people -will- enjoy this game. However, since I am not within those camps of people, it is a miserable experience and a terrible reminder of a little of what was good and a lot of what was bad in gaming back in the day, so I will not recommend it so as to represent my demographic.

[h1]Basic Information[/h1]
[b]Title:[/b]  Odallus: The Dark Call
[b]Developer:[/b]  JoyMasher
[b]Publisher:[/b]  JoyMasher
[b]Genre:[/b]  2D platformer

[h1]General Impression[/h1]
I grew up and had my first gaming console around the time that the “Metrodvania” craze was in full swing but I am always going to support the push for modernization, remastering, call it what you will. Being stuck in the past can never be a good thing. I can admire Odallus’ courage and efforts of not standing out, but to simply blend in and offer either a nostalgic or a new taste, depending on the age of its players. Is it a bad game? Far from it. It perfectly emulates the feel and mechanics of a story-driven retro platformer. But it also carries on the flaws of those games. A simplistic chromatic pallete coupled with an equally shoddy set of sounds. Should I mention the rage-inducing difficulty? I remembered pretty fast why I stopped playing such games and moved on to other genres. 

If regenerating health and the large list of in-game hints you posses now in almost everything you play, seem like an extreme form of dumbing down, know very well that there used to be a time in which the only solution to a difficult game section was to either ambition yourself to overcome it, or to stop playing altogether. I’d say that qualifies as the other extreme to the one mentioned above. The thing that disappointed me the most about Odallus: The Dark Call is ironically, not even related to its gameplay. It charges an exorbitant asking price and it also has a set of “wonderful” DLCs which are little more than glorified sprite packs at 1 dollar a piece. Even more amusing is the fact that JoyMasher’s first project on Steam and Odallus’ predecessor is Oniken, a game that is built in similar fashion but far more decently priced. 

[h1]Strong Points[/h1]
+ Evocative of a bygone video gaming era.
+ Steam Trading Cards & Achievements.

[h1]Weak Points[/h1]
- Unbalanced difficulty.
- Ridiculous price tag and equally preposterous DLCs.

[b]Rating 5/10[/b]

Hi everyone coming from the humble bundle! I'm here to let you know what to expect.

everyone else, I give this game a SITUATIONAL RECOMMENDATION. I have problems with this game but I got it for a very small amount of money from the humble bundle. I don't have a controller so that may be the problem.  

I'm spoiling the gameplay, but not the story.

So right off the bat we are reminded of "dark fantasy" nes games like "castlevania". We have a great aesthetic, cool chiptune music, and an actually interesting enough story. So why is this only a situational reccommendation?

Well, the game seems to really like parts of old nintendo games that I don't like. Parts that shovel knight didn't keep. The difficulty doesn't actually feel very fair thanks to giving you a lot of holes in your abilities, theres parts of the game where the gameplay changes drastically along with a corresponding difficulty spike (don't worry, it doesn't go battletoads on you, though the mine cart sections aren't fun in any way.) Further, you never feel like you have a bag of tricks ready to use on most things. You have a sword, three subweapons, and maybe a charge function if you found three secrets.

You start the game with a sword with roughly similar feel to the belmont vampire killer. similar enough range and decent attack speed, without the delay. you better love the way it feels. the only upgrades for that specific weapon are an 2x attack speed buff and a 2x damage buff. It's not like super castlevania four where you can slash diagonally.

So alright, it hits hard but isn't very versatile. This game has sub weapons though! An axe takes the place of the knife, and although it can do more damage because it can pierce through multiple enemies and bounce off a wall and still do a little damage to the guy it just hit to get to the wall, it feels too situational to be helpful. The torch takes the place of holy water! It's great! its arc is a little awkward though. And its unusable underwater. I may get back to that. The spear feels like a worse castlevania axe to me. it has a predetermined arc with the final angle being straight down rather than at an angle, which makes sense, its a spear, but it doesn't go as high as the axe. this games sprites are huge so you can't really see above you enough to miss it, but still.

If you find a super special series of unmarked secrets, you can charge them up! but it takes 10 charges(!) and you can only keep 50(!). And thats fully upgraded! And they're all very situational. The Axe makes you charge like a flash through multiple enemies, the torch makes a fire shield which damages enemies (provided they're within licking distance) and the spear is the obligatory full screen monster that you won't use often because theres never a huge amount of enemies. None of them FEEL powerful enough to be worth it.

I have told you every way you can hit things now. Lets talk about the funnest part of metroidvania style things, which this kind of is, movement! It's okay. You get a double jump, a short range dash that I couldn't use well because you have to double tap a movement key, and a glide. cool.

As far as defense, you can find armor, but its not going to make you a meat shield. You can stop (most) projectiles by hitting them with your sword, which is super triumphant feeling, but you can't block melee attacks, and theres a LOT of those. your dash doesn't seem to have invulnerability frames either. And you can't heal unless you get meat or stew, and you can't carry them with you or anything. you have to buy them from a rather unfunny fellow for quite a bit of currency, or find them in chests.

so as you can see, if you are attacking a very fast, very powerful melee enemy, you are at a vast disadvantage. you can't block their attacks, you're rather slow unless you dash, but its a burst dash rather than a sustained dash, theres a maximum distance. And a very powerful very fast melee enemy (though he starts shooting fire and lasers in the second phase) is the first two phases of the final boss. I couldn't get past the third phase, the first two phases always wittled me down too much. 

Okay, but how is the rest of the game? is the level design cool? are the secrets hard enough to find?

Actually, I like most of the level design. I can narrow down my complaints to two things:

The mine cart section, which is in just one level. Its a mandatory level to get to the final boss, but its managable.

And the water sections which are in every single level of the game. They're there only to make sure you pick up a specific item to gate you from getting past them, and they're miserable. They're just miserable. They make you move slower, they remove a sub weapon from your arsenal (FIRE DOES NOT WORK UNDERWATER, BYE TORCH) and it adds this annoying woobly filter across the screen that starts moving faster if you're falling or rising. I did not like these parts.

So the game is fine. It's just fine. Not amazing. Not absolutely putrid. A little bit of a letdown, I was really looking forward to it, but a servicable game with some bits of brilliance. If this came out 30 years ago, it would have been a hit. But today I want something more polished and approachable.
