A Metroidvania Dark Fantasy Adventure that's pretty good.

[b]PROS[/b]
-Good Story
-Solid Fun Gameplay
-Good Level Design
-Good Music
-Upgrades & Collectables
-Hidden Paths

[b]CONS[/b]
-Might be too difficult for some people

[b]FEATURES[/b]

It starts out with a cutscene explaining the heroes current position in life but quickly throws you into it, going from point A to B but every level, including the first level, has a hidden path that unlocks another level.  This is where the metroidvania aspect comes into play as you need an upgrade from further in the game to access the hidden path.  It kind of is comparable to Castlvania: Lords of Shadow style of Metroidvania, except it's far more well done.  If you've read my review of that game then you already know why I hated it, but this game does a better job at going about it.  

There's also hidden items & upgrades such as weapons, equipment, heart pieces, etc.  It even has a vendor that sells you weapons, health, & lives in exchange for souls kind of like in DMC or Darksiders, but every time you buy from him the item goes up in price making it harder to utilize him if you buy from him too much.  This I think adds a bit more strategy to the vendor making you think before you buy.  Should I buy this chicken leg or traverse through the level more in search of food myself?  Or maybe I'll just buy some more lives instead.  There's also checkpoints in each level, sometimes near the vendor & sometimes not.  When you beat a level or exit to the main menu the game auto saves.  The main menu is like an overworld in the style of Super Mario World of sorts.  You choose which level you want to go to but it also shows you how many secrets you've found & bosses you've defeated in each level.  You can go back to each level at any time after beating it.

The enemy encounters & boss fights are patternized, so once you memorize what they do it's fairly simple.  The game does have a Veteran mode for those who want a greater challenge but it recommends it for people who already beat the game as it adds new puzzles & enemy locations.  It's basically a NG+ that you can choose at any time, but without the upgrades.

Gameplay is simple.  You move, jump, attack & use items.  It's another NES style game where you can utulize a NES USB controller if you have one with the Classic Control Scheme. If you've played Oniken, you know what I'm talking about.  The Classic control scheme is pretty much the same as it was in Oniken.  Up+B is your special weapon, A is Jump, B is Attack, Select is swap weapon, etc.  It almost makes me with I had a USB NES controller.  You could always choose the classic style anyways though & use it with a modern controller.

[b]OVERALL[/b]

Overall the game so far is very good.  If you like classic style games like Oniken, you'll probably also like this game.  If you didn't like Oniken, you'll still probably like this game.  It's not as hard but is still challenging enough to have that old school difficult vibe.  I recommend it for anyone who enjoys oldskool platformers, adventure or metroidvania style games or for those looking to check out a well done retro style indie game.

Покупая игру в ретро-графике, никогда не знаешь, будет ли она соответствовать ожиданиям эпохи. Odallus всем своим видом говорит, что он продолжает дело Кастельвании - и действительно, ему это удаётся. Игра вполне могла бы выйти в том году, если бы только влезла на картридж.

У игры есть всё, что ожидаешь от старой Кастельвании, хорошее и плохое. Здесь немного тугое управление, какое было у старых Кастельваний; секреты и исследование локаций играют ключевую роль; а боссы большие и жуткие. Новый уровень сложности открывается после первого прохождения. Разработчики немного добавили от себя в старую формулу: например, герой может цепляться за края платформ и подтягиваться. Зато сколько они заготовили контента! Уровни действительно большие и разнообразные, враги, препятствия и загадки - нетривиальные. Здесь есть и заплыв на лодке, и поездки в вагонетке, и вертикальные полосы препятствий в полёте... Также авторы оставили "классическое" управление с крестовиной и двумя кнопками, но нагрузили его способностями насколько было возможно - в частности, кнопка прыжка не только прыгает, но и делает двойной прыжок, и планирует. К концу игры освоить это необходимо. Другими вдохновениями для игры были Ghosts 'n Goblins и Demon's Crest, что тоже чувствуется в возможностях и движениях героя.

Что важно знать, начиная игру: прохождение нелинейно. Секретные локации - не какой-то бонус, а обязательная часть пути к победе. Даже предметы, необходимые для прохождения, не говоря уже об улучшенном оружии и броне, часто лежат в секретах (а не как в Метроиде!). Я считаю, разработчики упустили возможность с игрой распространять "статью" из Nintendo Power (или, по-нашему, Великого Дракона) с подсказками к игре. Воспользоваться ей или нет - уже выбор игрока. (Тем более что пользовательские руководства по игре почему-то почти отсутствуют.) Так или иначе, игра вполне проходима на собственной смекалке игрока (в крайнем случае с обрещемнием к Ютубу) за 8-10 часов на нормальной сложности. Правда, настоящая концовка будет только после 100%-ного прохождения повышенной сложности, но во времена Ютуба это не так страшно.

Единственное, на что действительно хочется пожаловаться - это главный босс. В то время как другие боссы следуют предсказемой схеме поведения, которую можно изучить за несколько попыток, первые две стадии главного босса не то что бы рандомны - но непоследовательны. Это вызывает не радость ("ух ты, умный босс!"), а негодование ("ну вот, придётся фармить жизни, чтобы попытаться снова"). Ещё у него длиннющий диалог перед каждой фазой, но он пропускается кнопкой "Старт". В игре есть досадные баги. Во-первых, постарайтесь не ставить игру на паузу на боссах. Один раз после этого босс просто пропал, а другой - игра вышла в выбор локаций - и это во время анимации смерти босса! Во-вторых, управление слишком чувствительно к двойному нажатию клавиш. Бег (двойная стрелка) иногда срабатывает сам собой, если вы неуверенно нажимаете "вперёд" или встаёте, прокручивая крестовину. Я даже подозреваю, что можно совершить удар двойной силы, если игра зарегистрирует кнопку атаки дважды за сотую долю секунды. Кстати, спамьте боссов атаками - если герой достаточно вооружён и защищён, это иногда помогает. Так или иначе, подобные баги встрачаются и на картриджных играх, так что игру это не перечёркивает.

Рекомендую всем, кто соскучился по Денди и Кастельвании!

Odallus: The Dark Call is an action filled, throwback styled, adventure platformer that stands on it's own despite endless comparisons to the games of yesteryear. 

The superficial stuff here is extremely polished. The art alone gets Odallus much deserved attention and praise. I found the sounds and music above average as well. Granted there are a great many indie games with fantastic throwback art and sound styles. But Odallus also delivers at it's core mechanics. The controls are extremely polished and tight. So smooth in fact I didn't even find myself lamenting the atrocious 360 d-pad because I was able to use the thumbstick fine! speaking of, I would say a controller is heavily recommended here. It is easy to pick up and play but worth the effort to master. The simple story kept my attention from the standard beginnings to the gruesome ends. The level design is truly top notch and each world is varied and worth the time to explore completely for the abundant secrets. Nothing is impossibly hidden or unfairly set up for memorization and perfection. This is a nice open platforming adventure that rewards you for taking the scenic route. I 100%'d the in game check markers on the default difficulty and came away with 7 solid hours of sloppy play.

What starts as perceived difficulty does give way to your growing boldness once you get more of a feel for it. I polished off more than one boss with my better equipment and pure attack spam. And while I don't see how you would make things more difficult without taking away continues or making things unfair, I do think the challenge ends up in the medium range for the game style. I could hardly count this against the game as there is a higher difficulty as well as achievement challenges that I admittedly won't be doing. So in the end it was the right difficulty for me, but the more self described hardcore might have to work harder for a challenge. It is a good step above casual though.

Another thing with this game is the comparisons it gets to the Old Gods of gaming. The recommended/positive reviews are ripe with comparisons to games but with little accolades for what Odallus does on it's own. I would actually stop short of calling this a "Metroid-vania", particularly the latter part. It draws the heaviest from those two franchises but there is plenty more inspiration as well. I felt a little of everything from Mega Man to Donkey Kong Country in there! Highlander and Blade Runner (the movies) aren't afraid to show up either. And to go even deeper with apples and oranges nonsense, the entire time I was enjoying this I was thinking "Man, this is everything Volgarr the Viking wasn't for me"... But. All of this is unfair. This game stands on it's own despite it's clear inspirations. While it'd be at home on a cartridge it brings new styles, enemies, and ideas. Notably that wonderful use of the widescreen format for inventory and information that most throwback games would insist throwing in a pause menu. Odallus: The Dark Call is it's own beast and deserves judgement on it's own. Including the praise. 

It has begun to find it's way into bundles and steep sales which as always is where the true value is. $14.99 USD is a bit rich for my blood but I wouldn't have been entirely upset had I spent that. Recommended!

25343830.review:
“Odallus:  the dark call” es un juego de plataformas estilo retro, con una estética, jugabilidad y dificultad calcados a los que pudimos disfrutar en su dia con una consola Nintendo NES. 

En él, encarnamos a un guerrero que, tras volver de una batalla, encuentra su poblado en llamas, destruido por terribles criaturas. La mitad de los habitantes están muertos o desaparecidos, y el resto han enloquecido. Tras buscar a su hijo, sin éxito, el guerrero recorre el pueblo en busca de alguna pista de su paradero e información sobre la invasión y su origen.

Con un estilo muy marcado, clara referencia de los primeros Castlevania, nos adentramos en un juego bastante divertido y en momentos, desafiante. Desde un mapa global de la zona, iremos desbloqueando nuevas áreas que explorar, al mismo tiempo que consee guimos ítems que nos ayudarán a alcanzar lugares que al principio no son accesibles, como todo juego “metroidvania” debe ser.

No hay que complicarse a la hora de jugar y juzgar a Odallus. Es un plataformas ligero, medido, que te hará recordar aquellos años dorados de las primeras consolas. Bajo ese aspecto retro, el juego esta bastante pulido. Los mapeados están bien construidos, llenos de secretos y con detalles que le darán variedad a la partida. Los enemigos, sin ser un alarde de IA, tienen pautas de ataque bastante buenas, que como antaño, nos obligarán a fijarnos en sus rutinas y a aprender a sortearlos mediante el clásico “ensayo y error”. Los jefes son asequibles, aunque algunos no pondrán las cosas fáciles a la hora de acabar con ellos, sobre todo llegando al final del juego. 

El juego cuenta con vidas, aunque una vez se acaben, podremos seguir jugando, eso si, desde el principio de el nivel en el que estuviéramos jugando. Los mapas pueden recorrerse las veces que se desee, y muchas veces nos pedirán que volvamos a otro mapa anterior para alcanzar una zona a la que antes no se podía llegar.

Un punto bueno que tiene Odallus es que posee dos niveles de dificultad. En el normal jugaremos al juego de forma normal, pero en Veterano, la cosa cambia bastante. Los mapeados están llenos de enemigos mas poderosos que en el modo normal e incluso aparceran enemigos nuevos que darán aun mas guerra. Ademas los ítems cambian su localización, por lo que el trazado de fases cambia por completo.

Con una duración de unas 7-8 horas si se quiere encontrar todo al 100%, y rejugabilidad en modo veterano, Odallus es un buen juego, cuidado y divertido. No es fácil, legado de los antiguos clásicos de NES, y por todo ello, creo que es una compra recomendada.

Valoración: 6,5 / 10

Embora ache extremamente competentes, não sou um grande fã deste estilo de gráficos, de trilha sonora. E de quebra havia jogado o próprio Oniken e não tinha gostado muito.

Muitas críticas positivas e recomendações diretas me chegaram neste tempo e enfim dei uma chance ao jogo.
E que sorte a minha ter dado uma chance! De um jogo que “não tinha muito a me oferecer”, Odallus passou a ser meu novo jogo Brasileiro favorito, lista onde figuram jogos incríveis como Chroma Squad e Aritana.

A princípio Odallus é um jogo comum, mas seu primeiro grande mérito é ter a consciência de que fazer um jogo estilo 8 bits não garante o direito de fazer um jogo antiquado, problemático e com a jogabilidade naturalmente mais limitada da época, como acontece com muitos jogos por aqui que tentam resgatar a atmosfera da geração 8 bits.

O clima de jogo de 8 bits para nos visuais, nas músicas e na nostalgia, porque  a jogabilidade é redonda, precisa, meticulosa.

O segundo grande mérito é um game design primoroso. Grande variedade de inimigos, boa variedade de ataques, movimentações e muitos detalhes que não comentarei para não dar spoilers. Cenários cuidadosamente concebidos, história simples, porém interessante, personalidade do universo criado, chefões, etc. Odallus faz tudo certo.

Para coroar o excelente game design, vem o elemento que me fez não conseguir largar o jogo até terminar: a dificuldade.

Como era de se esperar, Odallus não pode ser considerado um jogo fácil. Ainda que seja bem mais “amigável” que seu antecessor Oniken, não está perto de ser chamado de jogo fácil.
Porém a maneira como a dificuldade é apresentada, como ela evolui, como o jogo te pune pelos erros até que você aprenda a jogar e as maneiras que ele encontra para te recompensar por persistir são exemplares e ao invés de afastar e causar desinteresse te prendem mais ainda. 

Não é uma dificuldade que está ali somente para quem terminar o jogo sair dizendo que é hardcore ou a dificuldade artificial que tanto vemos em outros jogos: aquela que simplesmente multiplica inimigos na tela e aumenta suas barras de vidas, que jogam um ataque indefensável na sua cara a toda hora somente para que você tenha menos chances.

A excelente jogabilidade coloca o personagem em suas mãos, fazendo com que aprender a lidar com os desafios dependa exclusivamente de sua habilidade, atenção e rapidez de aprendizagem. Existe sempre algo novo acontecendo, algum inimigo novo, área não explorada. 

Se mesmo assim você acha que o jogo está fácil, jogue no modo veterano e com certeza ficará satisfeito (ou mais provavelmente deitado no chão em posição fetal, chorando sangue).

Odallus não tem um grande número de fases, mas estas possuem um bom tamanho para um jogo do gênero. Se você jogar sem pressa e explorando, provavelmente o jogo lhe renderá de 8 a 10 horas de diversão na primeira jogada. O backtracking e a vontade de jogar de novo contribuem para a longevidade.

A evolução dos desenvolvedores entre Oniken e Odallus é visível e Odallus não apenas me deixou com um sorriso no rosto ao concluir a aventura como também está me fazendo querer voltar, além de me levar a dar uma nova chance para jogos do gênero que eu não havia gostado antes, como Shovel Knight e o próprio Oniken.

Odallus é tecnicamente impecável e não deixa nenhuma ponta solta, uma execução primorosa.
É uma alegria muito grande de tempos em tempos encontrar uma pérola como esta perdida por aqui. Odallus tem muitas inspirações, mas tem personalidade própria, tem alma, tem algo único a acrescentar. 

Ver jogos Brasileiros com este nível de qualidade, que são bons sem precisarem de um “empurrãozinho” ou de argumentos que elenquem as enormes dificuldades dos desenvolvedores nacionais é motivo de alegria, otimismo e esperança. Um sinal de maturidade deste nosso mercado que mesmo com as barreiras tecnológicas e financeiras ainda resiste e cresce.

Parabéns JoyMasher! Jogo imperdível para fãs do gênero!

Soberbo, elegante, brilhante, brilhoso, estonteante, estarrecedor, marcante, frugal, perene e efusivo!
Pontuação final: 81/81. A nota que nem Pelé tirou.

OBS: a página da loja diz que o jogo não está em PT-BR, mas está sim.

24967832.review:
Before you buy, please be aware that this is probably not the game that you think that it is. I see a lot of comparisons to CastleVania and Shovel Knight, but I struggle to see the similarities. Odallus is the type of game that looks better on paper (or in screen shots) than it performs in practice.

First and foremost, if you are expecting a metroidvania style game, this is not it. Yes, the game does have back tracking, but it is not connected in one large world, it is hard segmented into different specific levels. This game is more similar to Demon's Crest for the Super Nintendo, which is not a bad thing, but please be aware of what you are getting.

Perhaps the most critical weakness of Odallus lies within the core gameplay mechanics. It wants to be a tightly controlled NES style platformer, but it does not live up to this expectation. The controls are very responsive, and in fact feel great at first. As you progress you will however notice that the hit detection leaves something to be desired as your character is honestly, just too large. The scale of the game does not work for the type of tight manuevering and platforming that the game expects. It's certainly not the worst I have experienced, but it could be much much better.

Onto the 2nd downfall, the music. Just take a look at this game. It deserves an inspired, gritty, hard cut NES synth style soundtrack. Unfortuantely the developer had a different vision. Outside of perhaps the first level, the music really has more of a dull and moody vibe. The tracks generally fail to pop out and give that punchy memorable vibe you know so well from titles like CastleVania.

Luckily, despite other drawbacks, Odallus is beautiful. The art is wonderfully detailed and converys a very dark and sinistar overtone throughout the game. If Odallus has one strong point, this is it, hand down. Unfortunately, this is also what makes the game rather misleading when basing your purchasing decision solely from screen shots.

Overall, I'd say the issue with Odallus is simply that...it's boring. I never felt excited about the levels, the music never got me pumped, the gameplay isn't refined enough to keep me coming back. It's a dull muddy experience that is carried by some excellent art direction. If you are going to buy this game, I recommend that you watch some videos of the gameplay first. 15 dollars is too steep, but at about 5, I'd say it's right where it needs to be. Regardless, I am not going to recommend this game as it fell short of delivering a memorable and fun experience, time could be better spent discovering old NES classics you have never played, or replaying the good ones you already know.

I personally love me a good 8-bit Castlevania, even more so when it absorbed Metroid into its amorphous gelatinous mass. So I have no problem saying that "Odallus: The Dark Call" is a decent throwback to that entire genre. I won't spoil anything regarding the gameplay, as it's largely self-explanatory from the start if you've played Castlevania or Metroid (If not, why not?). However, there is one gripe I have with the game and that's the spike in difficulty right at the end.

So I've nearly beaten "Odallus" and have collected everything in the game, but that final hurdle is quite a doozy. Anyway, the fight begins with a largely equal opponent, being able to deflect attacks and special weapons is his main attraction. Basically, the player has to bait out his attacks to deal damage, which wasn't really needed in the entirety of the game up to this point but I guess that's the final bosses charm. However, his attacks are erratic and without a set pattern when they are baited out, sometimes he'll do a three-hit combo and other times just a single strike all of which throw you across the screen, go through any invincibility you may have, and take a heart each. All of this is manageable, but it's rather jarring since it hasn't come up until now.

Once that fight is done there's a little talking time, and then begins phase two which is step up the intensity scale. Your foe gets a slew of new attacks, in which he has more mobility, has projectiles, and an invincible super move along with his attacks in phase one. It's about here when I noticed that it was a lack of detail on the controls, sometimes I'd need to use the dash to get out of a situation and it wouldn't respond. Normally this wouldn't be an issue, but in the final fight it can result in some serious life complications (mostly with the life part).

I haven't even reached the third stage of the fight yet, but that's largely because the first two phases are a seriously long, drawn out affair. However, beyond that little spike near the end, the game is largely quite tame and can be played at a decent pace. "Odallus" is a decent challenge for those looking for an old school Castlevania-esque adventure, so I will recommend it even if it has that difficulty spike.

Экшн-платформер в графическом стиле старых игр. Если Oniken был абсолютно линейным, то в Odallus уже присутствует нелинейность и элемент исследования. Большинство игр с исследованием имеют огромную карту, поделенную на районы, тут же у нас имеются только отдельные локации. В каждом уровне есть несколько выходов, ведущих по разным путям. В принципе, все равно придется пройти все эти уровни, чтобы добраться до последнего босса, но порядок прохождения некоторых уровней можно определить самому.
Как и в любой игре с элементом исследования, здесь есть много предметов, что-то дающих главному герою: увеличение лайфбара, увеличение боезапаса дополнительного оружия, новые способности и т. д. Из перечисленного обязательно находить только дополнительные способности, которые понадобятся для преодоления каких-либо преград, остальное не обязательно, хотя и во много упрощает жизнь игрока.
Отдельно стоит отметить грамотный дизайн уровней, на которых нам необходимо применять новые способности. Большинство игр с элементом исследования грешат однообразными локациями, кучей способностей, про которые забываешь после одного-двух применений. Здесь же все иначе.
Игра очень атмосферна за счет и внешнего вида, и подходящего саундтрека (хотя, в отрыве от игры его слушать так себе). Что-то вроде мрачного фэнтези.
В игре есть усложненный режим под названием Veteran Mode. Довольно адская вещь. Что интересно, в этом режиме добавили новых врагов, добавили новые участки уровней, полностью поменяли расположение всех предметов, увеличили урон от врагов, добавили боссам мелких мешающих врагов. Данный режим рекомендую проходить только тем, кто уже прошел игру, и она им очень понравилась и показалась простой. Остальным к данному режиму лучше и близко не приближаться.
В целом, игра мне очень понравилась. Не так часто можно найти хорошо проработанные и качественные инди-игры. Из минусов можно отметить только некоторую медлительность персонажа как в плане передвижения, так и махания мечом на ранних этапах игры (конечно, можно к этому привыкнуть, но некий неприятный осадок остаться может).

22757796.review:
Indie games on Steam claiming to be inspired by the classics and not living up to it is pretty much old hat at this point. So I wouldn't exactly blame anyone for reading Odallus' store description and giving it a pass - but if they did, they'd be missing out on a modern classic. Odallus definitely lives up to all three of those series, and is proof you can still make games like them. 

JoyMasher's last game, Oniken (which I would also gladly recommend), was inspired in large part by Fist of the North Star, and Odallus has its own 80s manga inspiration in Berserk, which you can see in a lot of the enemy designs and some story ideas. You play as Haggis, a soldier-turned-hunter who returns to his village one night to find it ablaze, as a local lord has invaded, killed almost everyone, and kidnapped his son. What's worse, people are transforming into demons. It's definitely dark fantasy, which gives it a unique flair compared to Castlevania and Ghouls and Ghost (though not quite Demon's Crest).

Gameplay-wise, Haggis has his sword, which has a decent amount of range, as well as three sub-weapons: an axe that goes straight, a torch that goes downward and causes a fire for sustained damage, and a spear that flies up in an arc. They're all useful in their own right and can help you out a lot against certain enemies. Haggis also feels very tight to control, and while there are some tricky jumps it never felt like the game was unreasonable at all. The game's bosses also all pose a threat, but are fair about it.

Odallus also has some Metroidvania elements to it, as the game's Ghouls and Ghosts map contains several bonus levels you won't be able to access immediately, and every level has things you'll need the ability to push big blocks or glide to get to. It also lets you save and head back to the map whenever you want, meaning you don't need to go through the whole level again just to find whatever you're looking for. I beat the game in about five hours, but there is an extra difficulty mode that I hear changes things up a lot. All in all, if you're jonesing for some new Castlevania stuff, Odallus could tide you over quite nicely before Bloodstained is finished.

22582066.review:
This is an excellent retro platform adventure game.  It draws inspiration from many games during the NES era, while integrating some modern mechanics to keep things interesting.  Initially the homage to the first three Castlevanias is very apparent, the graphics, level select and movement all bring back a familiarity that even later Castlevania's have trouble envoking. The level design and game mechanics also pay homage to many other franchises from that era as well.  
   Progressing through the levels I found areas that reminded me of jumping through the tree tops in Wizards and Warriors, a mythology and backdrop as rich as The Battle of Olympus and plenty of secret areas initially unaccessable which would require me to return with specific relics that allow me to perform great feats much like a Zelda game.  
   Then there are the bosses fights.  These delightful bouts with demon knights and giant monsters will seem familar to anyone who has played Castlevania or Metroid but the boss fights also draw influence from modern games such as Dark Souls.  The patterns for some of the bosses are incredibly complex, drawing the perfect amount of anxiety between each move. I'd fumble and die many times before learning their entire cycle.  By the end I'm ducking and hanging off of edges, jumping and cleaving all in perfect sync creating some of the most fluid and dance like boss battles I've witnessed in a game. 

This game has a lot of depth to it, and despite borrowing heavily from so many classic games, once the rose coloured glasses associated with the nostaligia it invoked wore off it is a well polished and interesting game that holds it's own weight.  The player has lots of control over the character, you can climb ledges and move blocks, trade with merchants, or find relics to add some extra abilities.  Each level drawing from a different inspiration presents a smörgåsbord of playgrounds to explore each one unique in its play style while all keeping the same familar control.

Odallus: The Dark Call è proprio uno di quei giochi che ti fanno venir voglia di fare una recensione.
Il gameplay alla Metroidvania e lo stile Dark Fantasy si combinano in modo straordinario in questo titolo indie.

La trama parla di Haggis, il protagonista, pronto a tutto per andare alla ricerca di suo figlio in un mondo in cui gli esseri umani impazziscono e i demoni compaiono di continuo.
Nonostante la trama sia molto ridotta, e lasciata ai momenti iniziali, poche bossfight e, ovviamente, all'epilogo, la storia che essa racconta non è lasciata al caso. Certo, nulla di nuovo, in confronto alla mole di trame ormai esistenti nel mondo, ma di certo non è lasciata al caso. Approfondire l'argomento porterebbe a spoiler, motivo per cui passiamo a parlare del gameplay.

La mappa di gioco è alla Castelvania III: gioca un livello, sblocca il prossimo, rigioca il vecchio livello selezionandolo. A mio avviso si tratta di un ottimo approccio, se parliamo di un Metroidvania Indie.
I potenziamenti fanno sempre ripensare ai capitoli più famosi targati Konami e Nintendo, senza però scendere nel banale.  Come ogni gioco di questo genere che si rispetti, a inizio gioco ci si sente molto deboli rispetto allo scenario in cui ci si trova, ma i potenziamenti ci faranno sentire sempre più indistruttibili. Tranne beh, contro il boss finale.

Il livello di difficoltà è medio-alto. Non si tratta di uno scoraggiante "difficile" a cui solo i giocatori più bravi riescono ad adeguarsi. Il gioco è divertente e non fa sentire troppo pesantemente le morti.
Come i vecchi titoli su console Nintendo, avremo a disposizione 4 vite che, una volta terminate, riporteranno il giocatore a inizio livello invece che all'ultimo checkpoint.

Per i giocatori più abili, inoltre, è presente una Veteran Mode e diversi achievement che puntano ad aumentare il livello di difficoltà (come ad esempio arrivare a completare il gioco senza aver preso i potenziamenti della spada e/o dell'armatura) tra cui anche una speedrun.

Odallus è un gioco di quel tipo, un concentrato di platforming ed esplorazione che vorresti giocare più di una volta, che ti dà incentivi nel farlo e che ti lascia soddisfatto a fine gioco dopo tutte le imprecazioni urlate.

Vale i $15€ che costa?
Assolutamente si. Beh, certo aspettare uno sconto vi incentiverà a comprarlo, ma assolutamente, se avete 15€, vi piacciono i metroidvania e volete un nuovo gioco che vi lasci soddisfatti, Odallus è qui per voi.

Tel un Castlevania, Odallus The Dark Call sent bon le old-school de l'époque de la NES, autant dans ses mécaniques, dans sa forme que dans sa difficulté.

Niveau graphismes, on est donc dans le pur 8-bits tout ce qui a de plus classique, même si le jeu se pare quand même d'une forte identité visuelle. Vous évoluerez dans un monde très héroic-fantaisy, et souvent assez glauque, en particulier vis-à-vis du design de certains ennemis. Les animations sont simples mais claires, tout comme les hit-box, ce qui va de pair avec un gameplay assez solide. Autre aspect assez bien foutu, toute l'interface est visible à l'écran (points de vie, armes, reliques obtenues, ...), ce qui, en plus de donner un cachet arcade au jeu, s'avère très pratique.

Niveau gameplay donc, le jeu se veut action-RPG, avec une touche pour l'épée, et une pour le saut, rien de plus simple. Il y a néanmoins un petit côté Metroid, puisque vous avez la possibilité de rejouer les niveaux pour y découvrir divers secrets (améliorations de santé, ...) et surtout d'autres niveaux cachés. Vous pourrez ainsi obtenir de nouvelles capacités pour progresser ou bien de nouveaux équipements pour vous faciliter la tâche. Car oui, Odallus The Dark Call reprend aussi la difficulté de l'époque, le début du jeu notamment est assez costaud, car vous avez très peu de vie et les ennemis font mal. Par contre, comme d'habitude arriver à finir le jeu procure une très grande satisfaction.

Le seul point noir selon moi, outre la difficulté pouvant être un peu rebutante, est le scénario très cryptique dans lequel on a un peu de mal à se plonger. Les musiques non plus ne sont pas inoubliables.

Bref, Odallus The Dark Call est une franche réussite, qui ravira les amateurs du genre en manque de challenge.

22307664.review:
A worthy successor to the action platformers of old, Odallus does pretty much everything right. 

tl;dr:

Game is great. Combat is precise and rewards thoughtful play. Areas are well designed. Backtracking is well designed such that you always get rewarded for your trouble. Difficulty increases steadily throughout the game. Platforming is not cheap and punishing, but is instead a lot of fun. The setting and plot of the game is reminiscent of Berserk. If you like Symphony of the Night or Mega Man X you will be right at home here. 

In-depth review:

The thing that really struck me about this game is that it is one of the fairest games I've ever played. Most other "retro" games nowadays bombard you with cheap deaths and bullshit enemies, but not this game. Every enemy and obstacle in the game can be overcome with precise timing, tactics, and spacing. Every enemy has an attack pattern that it will follow, which is what you as the player need to analyze and overcome. One or two bullshitty enemies aside, everything in this game fits that mold. Platforming sections are much of the same. Once you figure out what sequence of button presses you need, you can do it perfectly every time. If you can't figure out how to do it with just your sword, there are 3 sub-weapons available to help you. These sub-weapons are ranged attacks with different trajectories, similar to the knife, axe, and holy water in Castlevania. 

The other thing that really delighted me was the strict adherence to the action part of the action platformer genre. The difference between an action platformer and a regular platformer is the focus on combat. No instant death pits, no knockback when you get hit, no pixel perfect jumps, etc. Though the game has a lot of platforming sections, most of them are pretty easy and straightforward. It is the combat with enemies that will wear you down. A really cool feature of this game is the ability to parry enemy projectiles by hitting them with your sword. This allows you to stay on the offensive much more than you normally would be able to because now instead of jumping all around to dodge stuff, you can stay right up in your enemies face and block all his stuff while hitting him at the same time. This adds another layer of skill to the game, as well as forcing the player to think about the risk/reward of blocking projectiles. As I mentioned above though, enemies obey strict timings in their attacks, which you can master. In the end you feel like a badass while also feeling challenged. 

The last part of the game I want to talk about is the exploration and the secrets. It's really good. The game has a very open and vertical layout, more similar to Wizards and Warriors than to any Castlevania game. The game follows the same general formula as every metroidvania games. You will see a part of a level that is unreachable to you, making you say to yourself "oh, there must be an item that lets me get that". However, the item progression is very much non-linear in the sense that you will not get the double jump item right after you encounter you first jump that requires it. Most items like that are buried deep at the end of a labyrinth, usually requiring you to traverse a large area while hitting a bunch of switches that will lower a gate with an item behind it. The first time this happened I had no idea what to expect, each time you get an item (save for one instance) it is a complete surprise. This is a nice break from the scenario I described above where you can pretty much perfectly predict when you will get a certain item.

The reason the exploration aspect of the game is so good is becaue of the level design and layout. The level progression is basically taken straight from Castlevania 3. Every level has two exits, one that will take you to the next main level, and one "secret" exit that will take you to a different level. The levels aren't really secret as they are required to finish the game, but I'm going to call them by that name. I noticed that the secret levels have a higher difficulty level than the main ones, which is a nice touch because the game is designed such that you access those levels later in the game. What basically ends up happening is that you find an item in a main level, then go back through every previous level and secret level until you find a spot where you can get somewhere you couldn't before. This will often lead to another new item that will let you reach other new areas in other levels. This cycle continues until you have every item, but also gets more difficult as the later secret levels are quite a bit more difficult than the main levels. The game also tells you how many items there are to collect in each level so you don't to crazy trying to keep track, a much appreciated touch.

Of couse the game is not perfect so here I will talk about the stuff that I didn't like or stuff that could be improved on. The shops in the game suffer from severe Skyrim syndrome. What I mean is that they are nice to have in the beginning of the game and can be quite useful, but by the end you will be skipping every one becuase you never have the need to buy anything. In addition to this, your gold total is ever increasing with nothing to spend it on. This isn't really a problem as much as a nitpick, but I went in expecting at least something important to be available in the shop, but the only things to buy a healing items, sub-weapon ammo, and extra lives. Nothing new is ever added. 

The other thing I don't think is quite perfect is the bosses. The games combat is set up in such a way that once you figure out the bosses pattern, it becomes trivial to defeat. This is fine for regular enemies, but I would have liked to see some of the bosses with a rage mode that changed up attack timings and added new attacks. I also think some of the bosses could have done with some more health, I was able to kill some of them after just a few attacks. On the flip side though, this game has some incredibly creative and original bosses, which I love to see. At the end of the day though, defeating the bosses didn't really fill me with satisfaction as much as it filled me with the feeling that I had just completed a chore. 

Overall the game is fantastic and is the best retro style game I've played since they became a thing, even beating out Shovel Knight and Axiom Verge. I got it on sale but it's absolutely worth the full price.

- Simple but effective gameplay, everything you'd expect: attack, jump, double-jump, glide, dash, etc.
- Collect upgrades to get stronger: increase health, sub-weapon capacity, get new abilities and new equipment.
- Secrets: explore, solve puzzles, break walls, overcome tricky jumps and so on to find your prizes.
- Different game modes, and you won't just get new and stronger enemies but the whole run will be affected. Can't exactly trust your memories from a normal to a veteran playthrough(Alucard reference from SOTN maybe?).
- Some references to other games/ media.

Cons:
- Some bugs here and there, not gamebreaking at all, just annoying sometimes, like with the  minecart parts that sometimes you fall on land but can't move and this forces you to quit and re-start the whole level(might get a fix in the future, idk).
- Short, only 9 stages, although this fits the Castlevania style. It's important to note that there's quite the number of places to explore if you aim for a 100% run, and doing achievements further increases the play time. I've finished it all in 23 hours, but I'm not exactly fast.

To me it was a well worth game, the pros far exceed the cons, really fun gameplay, totally recommended to the fans of Castlevania/ Metroidvania, oldschool games and medieval fantasy like Berserk.

Don't let the Demon's Crest name drop fool you, this is 8-bit difficulty at its most fickle, which pairs poorly with an old school lives system. Though to its credit, you aren't forced to enter a lengthy password afterward.

The controlls are only marginally less stiff than those of the 8-bit Castlevania games, from which this Odallus is primarily derived. Seriously, do not play this game if you don't like the way the old Castlevania games handled. You even fly backward when you take damage. And yes, there will be water hazards.

Odallus is in need of a quality-of-life patch. I found a menu which can only be exited by scrolling to the bottom of a list, the stage select and "begin stage" functionalities are accessed separately; all things which would have been mildly grating even in the '80s. And to the horror of the TotalBiscuits of the world, the options menu is sparse, and only accessible before the game actually launches.

Technical problems and bugs: Odallus is picky about controllers. I ended up using an old SNES controller piped through a USB adapter. If you die during a boss fight, you'll occasionally end up with both the boss music and the stage music playing simultaneously. And after the second boss fight, I had to faff around to get the game to accept character input again - I found entering and exiting the start menu worked most reliably. It's worth noting that I began playing in windowed mode after suspecting the game didn't handle alt+tabbing well - some of these bugs may be attributable to that.

I appreciate what they were trying to do - believe me, I do - but this one's a bit low on playability.

Odallus is a fantastic homage to some of the most beloved classics in gaming, especially those of the likes of Castlevania and Demon's Crest. It takes the most acclaimed elements in these franchises and throws in a couple of extra qualities, most notably unlinear/exploration-based gameplay. In that sense, it actually feels like a fresh game on its own right rather than a mere clone of the gothic 8-bit games it drawns inspiration from.

It really is a game that deserves more attention than it gets. The art direction, in particular, just begs for it - from the delightful pixel art to the all-around catchy soundtrack, the developers really did a magnificient job trying to make it all feel like an authentic 8-bit-era experience in that regard. The level design is also one of a kind - the levels are generally long, yet are all really enjoyable. Each one is unique in its own right.

It is also worth noting that despite drawing huge inspiration from the Castlevania NES classics, this game plays real smooth - so if you aren't really fond of the classic Castlevania games solely because of the extremely tight gameplay, I would naturally suggest giving Odallus a try.

All in all, Odallus is some genuine fun for both 8-bit era enthusiasts and those into indies in general. It really is a game made out of pure, genuine effort, and one that deserves more appreciation than it gets. If you had some thorough fun with Shovel Knight or Axiom Verge, you should definitely give this one a go.

20372233.review:
Odallus is to Castlevania what Shovel Knight is to Mega Man.

While this may have some of you stampeding to buy, hold up! Odallus is great, but it's not for everyone. In fact, while I wholeheartedly recommend it to fans of Castlevania and other games of that ilk (and difficulty), it's not without its flaws and quirks. If you can look past a handful of non-gamebreaking (though maybe you'll need to repeat a level once or twice) bugs, some questionable gameplay decisions, and a script that's as filled with errors as the average NES port, jump on in (albeit perhaps on sale; I 100% the game in less than six hours. While I prefer my games on the short side, and think $15 is a fine price point for a game of this quality, some may feel that's too high a dollar to hour ratio).

Some things I liked:
The actual core gameplay is fantastic. Taking its cues solidly from Castlevania, but updated to be more user-friendly, combat is all about balancing offense and defense. Normal enemies are mostly easy fodder, but the boss fights range from mildly tough to rage-inducing (especially if you don't know where to hit, as sometimes it's not quite obvious [I'm looking at you final boss final form]). A handful of subweapons have varying usefulness, and you can eventually get sword upgrades that attack faster and deal more damage. 
The platforming is pretty great too, and unlike Castlevania, you can alter your jump after you've leaped - no more sailing into the abyss. Well, you'll still sail into the abyss, but you have slightly more control over your fate.

Except for the minecart level. That's just death over and over.

The levels are all unique and all very cool. A town being razed. An icy mountain. A forest. A watery temple. Each with their own enemies, boss fights, and items and gadgets to find.  Like a Metroid-style Castlevania game, you use these items to backtrack to different locations for different upgrades and equipment, and fortunately the game is incredibly backtrack friendly. In each, there are doors to open, floors to break, and bosses to fight. But once opened, broken, and slain, they remain that way; backtracking through levels becomes fun to find the last secrets, instead of a frustrating grind through a place you already mastered. It's a great way of balancing difficulty, and makes the last level very hard, but not overly infuriating, as parts of it stay beaten even after you fail.

The soundtrack. Damn, the soundtrack is fantastic. Crunchy retro tunes really set the mood, and help you feel exactly like a barbarian trying to avenge his ruined town and dead son. Or something like that, I can't really relate. Put that on the box, not a relatable main character.

Some things I thought weren't quite perfect:
I got stuck on the minecart level a few times because if you die above ground, sometimes you get stuck and have to exit to the main menu and start that level fresh.
Some boss hitboxes aren't well-defined.
Upgrades aren't just a happy bonus, but damn near essential for beating the game proper. Doing it without is possible, and there are achievements for it, but I'm a casual baby and could barely beat it with all the upgrades.


Overall, it's an excellent game, and as a big fan of Oniken (who couldn't beat it :() I'm pretty much down for whatever Joymasher does next. They truly nail the area between retro fanservice and modern quality-of-life improvements.

★★★★☆

It breaks this annoying trend with indie games where it's an excuse to have bad and lazy graphics and gameplay and just call them "retro style". Shovel Knight and Odallus are two of the only game's I've seen actually come close to replicating an old school 8-bit platformer both visually and mechanically. However since it mechanically plays like an 8-bit game, there are finicky 8-bit problems, like the "sticky" platforming for example. Odallus also takes back to days where things were so cryptically annoying sometimes it made you shut off the game until a buddy told you what to do. Some gameplay design also feels intentionally dated for no reason other than to replicate the feel of an NES game, like respawning enemies and bad pop in. These were issues with games that were either unintentional bugs or hardware limitations, neither which can be an excuse for modern PC gaming. However just as easily you can pick apart Odallus and find it's flaws, it's just as easy to fall in love with the charm of the game. The artstyle is fantastic, the gameplay is as good as it can get for it's goal of replicating an NES game, and the soundtrack is catchy and energetic. Honestly, I'm surprised Odallus launched under the radar because it is a very fun and interesting expirience that would remind many of Castlevania or Ghosts 'n' Goblins/Super Ghouls 'n' Ghosts with it's punishing (and sometimes straight bullshit) gameplay. (like Metroidvanias). You'll be going back and forth, but locations have lots of variety, 
so everything works out really really well.

This is a REAL classic game, just with typical technical limitations of the era removed.
No pseudo-retro pixelated BS that you see these days.

It also adds something old Castlevanias hadn't:
- Superb and very elaborate cut-scenes. It will blow your mind like Ninja Gaiden's cut-scenes did back in the day.
- You can always expect some reward for your exploration (unlike Castlevania II),
  also shortcuts, secret passages inside secret passages, teleports and other stuff make it all the more fun.
- You are not knocked back to the nearest danger all the time (unlike all Castlevanias), 
  and sometimes you'll wish you were actually knocked back, believe it or not.
- You keep all your stuff and level progress after Game Over.
- You can buy or find more continues.
- Very stylish visuals, resembling NES Castlevanias style (via reduced color palette)
- Pleasure to see a classic game at 60 fps and no sprite flickering / slowdowns common for the era.
- You can play it classic style with 2-button controller or with the modern 4-button one.
- You'll find all cool classic gameplay solutions in one game. 
  It also has some challenges old games couldn't even think of.
- As it was a standard earlier, the final boss will have all your skills tested. 
  Multiple phases, lots of damage, trick attacks, changing patterns. GIT GUD or die trying.

But new players shouldn't fear, the game will give you a brief introduction to
what a classic game feels like via top levels, while vast bottom levels and their bosses show you "the real deal".

Did you want a classic Castlevania? Or maybe at least a good clone? 
But who makes them these days? Joymasher does. But if sales figures will be as bad as they are now, I fear they will stop.

Currently sales of Odallus are marginal (below 4k copies), according to SteamSpy.
If you have been waiting for Konami to make a "more classic" Castlevania all these years, 
stop waiting fruitlessly and play Odallus instead.
Hope they'll do a sequel.

19129954.review:
[url=http://www.le-serpent-retrogamer.org/odallus-the-dark-call/]> Retrouvez cette critique en images sur le Serpent Retrogamer <[/url]

[b]Ce n’est pas un secret : le PC est une plate-forme reine où les indépendants se régalent, surtout ceux qui veulent rendre hommage aux jeux rétro d’antan. Alors que les fans de Metroidvania pleurent la disparition des jeux Metroid/Castlevania en 2D, une lueur d’espoir émane de Odallus : The Dark Call. Contrairement à Haggis, les Dieux ne nous ont pas abandonnés, nous ![/b]

[h1]Mon royaume pour du pixel[/h1]

Voici donc le deuxième jeu de JoyMasher, petit studio qui a déjà sévi chez les PCistes avec Oniken. N’attendez pas de moi une comparaison entre les deux titres, je n’ai pas eu l’occasion d’y jouer (mais promis je me rattraperai un jour). En tout cas, pour le petit frère, pas besoin de tergiverser : un simple trailer du titre montre que nous sommes en présence d’un « clone » des épisodes NES de Castlevania avec sa réalisation 100% 8-bits aussi bien sur le plan graphique que sonore. Encore une fois, les râleurs (comme moi) peuvent chouiner sur ce choix artistique qui pullule depuis tant d’années qui tire trop sur la fibre nostalgique dans un but purement démago’. Mais l’avantage, au moins, c’est que ça tourne sur toutes les config et même sur le netbook de môman. Et puis, il faut être honnête : c’est plutôt bien fichu, les décors et sprites sont maîtrisés d’une main de maître et une atmosphère rétro particulièrement envoutante s’impose au joueur. La cerise sur le gâteau, c’est d’activer l’option « filtre TV » qui rajoute des scanlines donnant l’illusion de jouer sur une bonne vieille cathodique. Ah, c’était la bonne époque les 80’s… même si je n’étais pas né !

Comme le veut la tradition sur les jeux du genre, les 3 lignes de scénario qui servent d’opening annoncent très clairement la couleur : on ne va pas jouer à Odallus pour sa narration. Malgré le peu de PNJs présents durant l’aventure, il est tout de même fort regrettable de ne pas avoir une petite traduction française malgré le choix de langue entre l’anglais, le russe et le… portugais. Le pitch central nous conte l’histoire de Haggis qui réclame vengeance après qu’un dark lord ait massacré son village et enlevé son fils. Allez hop ! Direction le château du grand méchant armé de notre gourdin de niveau 1. Chose très appréciable et qui donne le sentiment de tenir une manette NES dans ses mains : le jeu n’a que deux boutons d’actions. On constate d’entrée de jeu que les sauts sont ajustables en pleine chute, et que la physique offre de bonnes sensations loin de la lourdeur de certains jeux des années 80. En revanche, on ressent une certaine rigidité (chose voulue je suppose) avec les coups d’épée. La majorité du temps, il n’est pas possible de « combotter » un adversaire juste en martelant le bouton, il faudra donc opter une stratégie à l’ancienne qui consiste à frapper et esquiver rapidement via un saut.  Pour ne pas casser les codes imposés par les ténors du genre, on dispose de plusieurs armes de jet (hache, torche, lance) qui se lancent en maintenant la flèche haut et le bouton d’attaque. Rien ne peut être pris en défaut sur la maniabilité : Odallus mixe les phases de plate-forme et d’action avec succès sans que l’on se sente frustré… sauf peut-être dans les passages à bord d’un chariot de mine qui laisse un petit arrière-gout amer qui rappelle un certain Donkey Kong Country sur Super Nintendo.

[h1]Symphony of the Knight[/h1]

Au fil de l’aventure, on ne peut que tirer notre chapeau aux développeurs qui se sont arrangés pour caler ce qu’il faut en terme d’exploration et situations variées. Au joueur de résoudre quelques énigmes et puzzles (sans grande aide) pour progresser et toujours à lui de trouver les upgrades cachés comme les demi-cœurs de vie dans les niveaux (et sans mini-map pour se faire guider). Il sera également indispensable d’obtenir des reliques de double-saut, dash, etc. pour avancer et surtout terminer chaque stage à 100%. Ceci étant, il est intéressant de constater que Odallus n’est pas qu’un bête enchaînement de niveaux, chaque niveau a une sortie secrète qui donne accès un autre sur la wordmap. Les niveaux sont donc au nombre de 8, chacun a son propre lot de saloperies pixellisées qui fait office de bestiaire. Délicieusement répugnants, chacune des zones a un mini-boss et un gros bien immonde qui rappelle souvent la belle époque de Castlevania. Détruire ces 8 gardiens est la clé pour débloquer le niveau final. Jouissant d’un challenge relativement correct pour les habitués du genre, Odallus n’oublie pas de nous concocter un boss de fin en 3 phases assez ardues et un combat optionnel avec en récompense une armure ultime (et un poil cheatée). En revanche, la balance se déséquilibre à partir du moment où on abuse des armes de jet, surtout la torche.

Au final, que puis-je reprocher à Odallus le grand qui offre une copie quasi-parfaite à tous les niveaux de réalisation. Et bien mes amis, sachez qu’il est dans mon devoir de chercher la petite bête. Prenons par exemple la durée de vie. Bien que le jeu fasse des efforts pour varier les plaisirs avec son cheminement non-linéaire, on arrive à une durée de vie plutôt maigre de 4-5h en ligne droite. Bien entendu, il y’a toujours moyen de décrocher le 100% pour allonger le plaisir mais on grappille seulement à peine 1h de plus étant donné que la quasi-totalité des items auront déjà été trouvés durant l’aventure. La question de la re-jouabilité se pose également vu qu’il n’y pas de modes supplémentaires et rien à débloquer après. L’expérience globale n’est pas non plus sans défaut, j’ai moi-même été victime de petit soucis de scrolling avec la caméra lors d’une chute, d’un boss qui n’exécute pas son pattern et d’un blocage plusieurs fois de suite en discutant avec le marchand. On espère quelques futures mises à jour pour patcher ces petits désagréments.

[b]Cela va sans dire, mais Odallus : The Dark Call est une petite perle. L’équipe de Joymasher envoie une lettre d’amoureux aux nostalgiques tout en respectant l’héritage précieux laissé par les années 80-90 tout en marquant son territoire avec son univers glauque à souhait et une réalisation divine. En espérant que leur prochaine production se rapproche encore plus près de l’excellence.[/b]

VengeurMasquay

This company, Joymasher, seems to excel at NES style games.  This one is a superb mix of Castlevania, Metroid, and Astyanax.  It's got a dark story about gods abandoning the world and one man's quest to find his son and reclaim what little joy there is to be had in his life.  The sprites look great and the design work for the bosses is inspired with some horrific, sometimes even Lovecraftian nightmares staring you down.  Controls are tight and superb and the game has a plethora of secrets to find, with control schemes for classic NES controller, keyboard, or modern 360 controller.  It also does away with instant death traps and pits, for the most part, only taking a bit of health when you die...so in my opinion it's more polished than many old school NES games from way back when.  There are cut scenes and I wish we had more of them, but overall, there aren't too many flaws here.  If you want an old school NES game done right, with the polish and care of true pros, I say don't be dissuaded by this games price tag. Buy it.

18820913.review:
So yeah, I decided to write a review. I've probably never done this before.
tl;dr:
The game is cool and it does feel like an oldskul title.

Graphics:

The graphics are sometimes obviously much better (as they benefit hardware wise), using capabilities that were not available back in the day.
Their blend of pixel-art-style is unique and somewhat strange as they intentionally used very few colors for every character and creature in the game (less than you normally would expect from an actual 8-bit title). Unlike an actual 8-bit title, the sprites don't share colors often. Each sprite has it's own set of colors and each color-set is somewhat distinct and specific to a single sprite. This makes for a very crisp and clear display that also stirs some strange emotions at times. There was something very alien at times about the graphical choices in old games and I think this bizarre use of (very few) colors captures that very well and even builds up on this making for a very unique vibe that somehow melds in my mind with 80's and early 90's Heavy Metal albums.
The intro animation is pretty fantastic.

Gameplay:
The gameplay is rather good. It is very enjoyable with a joypad. I'd imagine that without one (using the keyboard), it would not be so much fun probably. You constantly feel like you are freshening up on your action platformer skills. You will improve if you play carefully and pay attention to patterns, doing what you can to learn from your mistakes. 
Exploring the game is fun and it is vast so there is plenty to explore for a few hours.
The weapon and armor upgrades feel right and the secrets are fun and rewarding to look for.

Challenge:
The difficulty in this game could be vastly mitigated by the weapons, armor and hearts you find along the way, as well as the shops that are simply a play to grab additional health and ammo.
Some enemies are harder to figure out than others. Some enemies are fairly easy once you understand their patterns.
The game isn't hard but it's also rarely too easy (although that does happen). This is subjective. Some people find it too hard and I feel there are areas in the game that are more challenging than others. Overall there are no annoying spikes.

Story:
The story is a pretty simple plot about Dark Gods, evil demons and a lone superiorly skilled soldier made demon hunter going around, searching and slaying more and more evil creatures that happen upon his path. The texts are pretty good and fit with the atmosphere of the game.

Sound:
The sound effects and the music are good, I've never felt the urge to listen to music in the BG when I'm playing this game even though I imagine that Heavy Metal would suit this wonderfully.

Overall:
* Do you like Metroidvania games?
* Do you prefer a gritty dark atmosphere in games?
* Do you like the aesthetics of old games like Golden Axe and Rastan?

If you answered yes, there's a good chance you"ll love (or like) this game.
It is pretty good. Don't think there is any other game on Steam that really scratches that itch. Well actually there is! Axiom Verge I believe but the two games are very different. If you are into this sort of thing you"ll probably end up playing both of them if that's within your time constraints.

17674421.review:
When I think of games like Ninja Gaiden, Shinobi, Castlevania, and Ghouls 'N Ghost, my childhood comes back to me and the countless hours I spent playing these games and occasionally raging. The stories were told through minimal pixel art and music was chip tune heaven. These games hold a special place in my heart not only because they were amazing to play as a kid, but because they used what they had for the time giving story, music, tone, and narrative through very little means. These games are accomplishments in game design as much as they are fun to play.

Odallus seeks to capture the magic of games of yesteryear and bring some classic gaming nostalgia along with it. I am happy to say it does this in oodles and with it's own unique style. Odallus like the aforementioned titles is a side scrolling action/platformer, paying homage to each title in its own unique way. The story of the game is about a great warrior in a dark time, the gods have turned their back on all humanity and demons and monsters begin to reap souls to their delight. The warrior (you) must fight the onslaught of an army of darkness in search of his son. This immediately sets the tone to one of dark, gothic, horror, and this is captured perfectly. The monsters are grotesque, the architecture is strange, even the save point is a giant skeleton!

One thing that immediately caught my eye was the amazing pixel artwork in the game. Yes, the monsters are hideous and ugly but damn they look good. Cut scenes are reminiscent of Ninja Gaiden(NES) where they are told in clips and scenes that reveal more of the story of Odallus. The main game itself is simple and retro in style. Each area has a color palette and tone to it. This doesn't mean that Odallus is boring to look at, but in fact makes each area feel unique and distinct from the last you were in.

The gameplay is also rather deceptively simple, there is only about 8 buttons for you to manage, that's including the start button. You have an attack, movement and special. There are items that you can also pick up in the game like axes and torches that you throw at the enemy. Things do get a bit more complicated in the late game but I will just cover the basic experience from go. One thing Odallus excels is fantastic level design. The levels are not necessarily straight forward to the boss, rinse and repeat. Matter of fact there are plenty of paths and secrets to discover, even in the first level. This is what takes the simplistic gameplay and makes it unique and challenging. You could just rush to the boss and clear the level but if you take time to explore, gather power ups, heart pieces and other upgrades, these make future battles much easier. Power ups can be found Shovel Knight style, littered about the game, perhaps behind a hidden wall or requiring another power.

Speaking of the battles, Odallus just like games of yesterday, is damn hard! Your character isn't exactly the most agile fighter in the world. Enemies are just as dangerous as the boss, are numerous and respawn very quickly. You constantly must be on your toes or take needless damage. There are things in the level to counter act this, from shops to chests containing standard hunks of meat. There are times that I did rage quite a bit, as Odallus can sometimes have difficulty spikes. Bosses are standard as well, having patterns that once mastered become second nature. I shouldn't forget to mention the map system that let's you choose where to explore. Making returning to earlier levels easy and downright required.

All this is backed up by many modern touches and features. Rebindable keys, controller support, TV mode, and leaderboards. The UI sits on the sides of the screen displaying all important information and upgrades. This is one area that I would've loved a bit of an option on to turn on/off depending on when I needed it. This is a minor complaint and hardly an issue. The only other area that I had an issue was the start up menu. While it was easy to use, on my screen it was super tiny. Sometimes I had to squint to see what I was looking at.

Other areas of the game are also given the classic retro touch, such as the sound track and sound effects. Chiptunes are plentiful having the same gothic tone. This gives the game a definite Ghoul 'N Ghost vibe and every level was like a flash back to a much simpler time. Matter of fact that's how you could just sum up Odallus. It's a flashback to a much simpler time but does things right when it comes to modern features. Things like voice-acting aren't present because that would throw off the tone of the game. 

The replay and game length are solely dependent on the player's drive to find all the hidden secrets in the game. This does require retreading the same areas sometimes, so that can be seen as repetitive, but most of the time it would involve an area you haven't been through. The game can probably take anywhere from 5-7 hours depending on your skill level. 

I think anyone who loves retro style games will love everything Odallus has to offer. With Shovel Knight giving a resurgence to these style of games. It really deserves your attention if you are looking for something similar. While the game isn't super innovative, it masters the features that we have all come to love and expect from these types of games. From classic power ups, chiptunes, and great pixel art, Odallus brings back the old school flair with style.

A very ambitious game from the makers of [i]Oniken[/i]!  The first thing you'll notice is that the game is very beautiful; the dreamy pastel pixels that comprise the game world would be right at home in an experimental late NES game, and the developers have even gone to the trouble of restricting colors used per sprite in order to give the assets a more authentic vibe! The last boss poses a suitably epic challenge, though, and the rest of the game is a great deal of fun even if it doesn't induce you to curse your own birth.  [i]Odallus[/i] is a bit like [i]Rondo of Blood[/i] in that it features gigantic, sprawling levels that remain discrete -- it never takes that final turn into the labyrinthine world of the metroidvania.  Consequently, you won't be lost if you take a lot of time between play sessions.

I have but one complaint:  some of the English is pretty bad.  With everything else [i]Odallus[/i] has going for it, I don't suppose that's much of a big deal, but I found it pretty jarring (most of the runic story slabs border on incomprehensible). Odallus: The Dark Call es un juego que todo amante de lo retro, en especial de la epoca de la NES o SNES, debería tener en su colección de juegos.

Por un lado tenemos sus gráficos con clara inspiración a los juegos de la 8 bits de Nintendo. Oscuros, ambientales y con el encanto pixelado que deja a nuestra imaginación gran parte del trabajo. Sin duda se han tomado bastantes libertades que no podrían estar en un juego de NES: Hay varios sprites en pantalla, son de tamaño bastante mayor a lo habitual, varias capas de scroll parallax y sin pizca de ralentización o parpadeo. Aunque tal vez eso hace que la emulación se pierda, tambien gana en lo impresionante que es el titulo gráficamente.

La música intenta también imitar el chip de sonido de una NES con bastante acierto, creando una melodías que encajan perfectamente con la ambientación, pasando por melodías lentas y ominiosas durante la historia y con piezas rápidas y trepidantes durante el juego en si. No son tan memorables como las melodías de, por ejemplo, Castlevania en su época de NES, pero están a un buen nivel.
Los efectos de sonido en general tienen la fuerza suficiente para resaltar, y llaman las atención las imitaciones de "voces digitalizadas" que hace el juego, cumpliendo a un buen nivel.

En el apartado jugabilidad es también un clara imitación de un juego de NES, fácil de asimilar, de pocos botones y responde bien. Sus mecánicas son simples, fácil de hacerse con ellas, y a medida que nos hacemos con nuevos objetos y habilidades estas se pueden ejecutar con bastante facilidad. Tal vez un escollo inicial es lo "torpes" que son los espadazos del protagonista, que son lentos y con una colisión bastante extraña done la espada a veces parece quedarse corta al golpear para lo grande que es. Esto esta hecho a propósito para buscar las versiones mejoradas y con el tiempo nos adaptamos, pero no quita al sensación de que si fallamos un golpe no es nuestra culpa, si no de lo mal que lo hace el protagonista. Es curioso como este efecto también lo encuentro en otro juego de la misma compañía, Oniken.

En el apartado desarrollo si nos encontramos con el escollo importante. Como juego de plataformas cumple muy bien, los retos van mejorando a medida que avanzamos poniendo a prueba nuevas tácticas y las habilidades que vamos encontrando con nuevas mecánicas de nivel en nivel, representando un juego retante pero sin abusar de la paciencia del jugador. Los jefes son retantes, tengas o no las habilidades requisito para superarlos, y requieren varios intentos para ser derrotados teniendo de aprender sus patrones y ataques, pero resultan siempre posibles de vencer.
Pero como aventura... se queda corto, muy corto tanto a nivel de duración como profundidad. Al principio todos los descubrimientos son impresionantes y te emocionas con lo que descubres. Pero una vez ha pasado la primera impresión, los descubrimientos se convierten en algo mecanico sin requisitos adicionales a nivel de inventiva o imaginación, acostumbrándonos a ver "muros que romper" o "bloques que empujar", volviéndose todo demasiado obvio. Comparándolo con "Demon's Crest" de SNES, en ese juego había una serie de secretos obvios para las mecánicas más básicas que te permitían acceder a las habilidades o objetos mínimos para completar el juego, mientras había otra serie de secretos más complejos y elaborados que te obligaban al jugador a romperse más el coco y masterizar las habilidades si quería completar el juego al 100%. Aquí se ha optado por no exprimir tanto y ser menos exigente con el jugador, siendo muy probable que termines tu primer partida con el 100% del juego completado sin dificultad y en un tiempo bastante corto de apenas 3 horas.
Ademas, el juego no da pie a ser rejugado. Si en "Demon's Crest" el progreso final determinaba distintos finales para la aventura, siendo incluso posible acabarla con los menos objetos posibles, consiguiendo el final más malo, aquí  solo hay una extensión del final normal al conseguir el 100% del juego, el cual ya se ha dicho que se consigue sin mucho secreto, y no tiene casi diferencia con el final normal. Si bien se que tiene algunos logros que aun no se han desvelado y parecen secretos, pinta que seran easter eggs más que algo que añada rejugabilidad al juego. 

En definitiva, un gran juego par aquellos que buscan rememorar los dias delante de la NES o SNES, recomendable para los fanaticos de las plataformas en 2 dimensiones, pero un bocado demasiado pequeño para aquellos jugadores con ansias de aventura o de romperse el coco con un juego. 

Puntuación: 8,5/10

Oniken was a tribute to the... not-so-great linear cyberpunk action platformers in the style of Power Blade or Shatterhand. Developer Joymasher has constructed a much more solid effort in the form of Odallus: The Dark Call, a more exploration focused affair set against a swords and Satanism backdrop. Though the term "Metroidvania" is being thrown around with this one, Odallus actually has more in common with the NES Strider game than with pre-SotN Castlevanias. In short, it's what I had hoped Rondo of Blood would be before I learned that Rondo of Blood isn't actually that good.

The thing that makes this game click for me is, while the stages are laid in the framework of "go from point A to point B and fight a boss," the areas themselves are actually quite massive and reward a bit of poking around. It follows the motif of being locked off from a certain area before collecting THE THING that opens that area up, but discovering the alternate exits in the stages that lead to their sublevels or just seeing the way the routes loop back on each other is a reward in its own right for exploration nerds. It can get a bit overwhelming at times, the game has no automap and unless you're taking diligent notes, you're going to have a bit of a time remembering where you have and haven't poked around in your search for that last secret in a given stage. However, this approach is a bit more organic and fulfilling than "color in spots on a map" and helps extend a rather brief game in a manner that doesn't feel tacked on. I'm not sure exactly how much is required to uncover before you're allowed to make it to the final stage, but we'll probably get a good idea with future speedruns or Games Done Quick events.

The game does have some rough edges. While controlling Haggis is responsive enough for the most part, combat can be frustrating given the short reach of your sword and the sometimes dubious hitboxes. If your experience is anything like mine, you're going to end up cheesing the hell out of a boss or two just to keep the game moving. Jumping while attacking is especially wonky, since this is one of those games where jump height is controlled by the duration of the button press. There's sometimes some weird stuff going on with the scrolling, each stage will have arbitrary spots where the screen has to quickly scroll vertically to reveal some area that's off the beaten path. The effect can be disorienting and at times even causes Haggis to jerk around like a catfish on deck. I'm also not sure if some of the grammatical errors in the admittedly over-dramatized dialog are an intentional tribute to the rushed localizations of the 8-bit era, or just natural goofs. They don't show up quite frequently enough to suggest that they are intentional, but they're about the only comic relief in a story that plays it 100% straight.

If you prefer your sprites and your gameplay decidedly on the 8-bit portion of the spectrum, definitely give Odallus a shot. Visually, it's a gorgeous game, even at its most grotesque, and it will probably hit the same kinds of buttons that Shovel Knight did for players who grew up in the pre-polygon era. With just a little more polish it could have been a perfect 10, but it's still worth the price of admission.

More Reviews @ TheVideogameBacklog.com

Ever want to relive the experiences and emotions that you had when you played Ghost ‘n Goblins on the NES or maybe the SNES version back in the day? Or maybe you have always loved a good side-scrolling challenge with a retro twist… Odallus is calling your name. It’s kind of a dark calling, but it’s there saying hi.

Odallus starts you out on a hunt when you notice something is amiss back at home. You know how it goes though. You see some smoke at your village and you run back as fast as you can, but no matter what you do, it’s always mostly gone before you arrive and all you can do is dig through the rubble. You find out that some cult of weirdos is behind it and they’ve got your kid to boot! There’s only one thing a man with the name of Haggis can do (yes, his name is Haggis and yes it grows on you): grab your sword and go share it with some evil creatures. Well, that’s a start at least right?

The developers really went out of their way to make Odallus aesthetically old school. Odallus really looks like an 8-bit game. The way the character moves, jumps and attacks all take me back. There is obviously additions to the classic formula like weapon variety combined with the ability to switch between them and lack of pixel jumping like when a cartridge gets old or the system needs cleaning. Some things you can just leave out when you go for this genre though. There is also some secret paths that will have you coming back to the beginning of the game to find the areas with hidden power-ups or different paths to lead you through another way to get to the end.

The difficulty is probably the main thing that will grab people’s attention and get them to come over to the Odallus side in the first place. (That’s just a big thing currently.) I don’t feel it’s your usual difficulty that some Indie devs have been going for lately. A lot of the time it’s a speed or overabundance of enemies/bullets/spikes that will overwhelm you in most recent “hardcore” sidescrollers. JoyMasher hit the nail on the head with the legitimate retro feel. Odallus’ difficulty seems to be based on your level of patience. Nothing will jump out of a spot that wasn’t there before or what-have-you or force you to move your fingers way faster than you may be able to. It’s a classic “slow and steady wins the race”. When you start getting frustrated and rush into things is when you’ll die. Calm down and take your time and measure your enemies (bosses included). There’s no time limit (thank goodness) so you have no reason to speedrun Odallus… unless that’s your goal. If that’s the case then, hurry up man! There is an achievement after all.

Score: Gewd/Tasty!

I haven’t run into many issues with Odallus: The Dark Call after the few patches they put out a little after I initially downloaded the game and before it officially launched. Since then it’s been smooth sailing and I’ve really enjoyed myself. That, of course, is only because I’ve learned to walk away after a few deaths on the same area. When I get too frustrated I tend to just walk away for a very long time. With a myriad of level types and the ability to obtain new weapons (and suck at using all of them other than the sword) there’s actually a lot to experience here. There are puzzles, platforming and stabbing stuff all while pulling off the retro feel better than most, Odallus is pretty dang good. That’s coming from a guy who doesn’t appreciate too much of a challenge anymore either (I’m getting old and just want to have fun, get off my back!) If you’re looking for a nostalgia trip, a retro-themed game, or just a game that won’t let you be too mindless, Odallus will satisfy your hunger. Now, go save your kid!
